Although there is a warning that additional flavor can be added to the bowl, I've never been to a great ramen shop where any additional flavor has to be added to the base broth. If you end up here, definitely order the extra flavoring with your meal. I don't think I would come back here unless there were no other alternatives for a late dinner. If you are desperate for some ramen, hit up Monta down the street.

Love the noodles and service at Ramen Sora! The servers are really attentive and understanding. 

Their one drawback is the broth, which is a bit too salty for my taste. However, their miso broth is full of great flavors, and if you're a fan of spice, I recommend adding the spicy meat! Their rice dishes are surprisingly amazing! If with a friend, order a ramen and rice dish to share! 

Ramen Sora still provided a solid meal, and I'd be willing to go again to try other menu items.

I was told about Ramen Sora by some friends that this ramen was better than Momta's.  I am a BIG fan of Monta so I had to see for myself.   I went to check it out with three coworkers.

I had the spicy miso ramen with green onions and a mini curry bowl.  Two of my co- workers also went with the spicy miso.  One tried the Nori miso.

Overall I would say that the spicy miso was right there with Monta's.  In retrospect, I should have ordered a normal miso to make a better comparison.  Overall I would say that Ramen Sora is right there with Monta.

This ramen place is by far the best ramen I've had in Vegas (The other being Jinya). Good service, good miso ramen = Happy customer. The chashu bowls are bomb af. Overall, great experience and good food. 10/10 would recommend to a friend.

My cousin recommended this place for some good ramen and while in Vegas we couldn't resist and try this place out before heading back home to CA. This place is located in Chinatown and not far from the strip. Place is small and if you arrive during busy traffic around lunch time or dinner time, expect to be on the waitlist. 
Luckily the place wasn't too busy and waited a quick 10 minutes, only because we wanted our town table, versus sitting on a long table with others.

Their menu is short and sweet, and exactly perfect if you know exactly what you want. You chose base soup you want and then the type of bowl you want. The bowls vary in what kind of ingredients in there, some with more chashu, no egg,  with egg, etc, they even have a vegetarian bowl. I went with the Spicy Ramen and my boyfriend got the Deluxe Sora Ramen both with the Miso base, and also the Large Chashu Rice Bowl. 

Food came pretty quick and by the time we were finished, we were both stuffed. I really enjoyed my Spicy Ramen. It wasn't too spicy at all, just perfect. The Deluxe Sora was also really good. They have generous amount of the chashu. The rice bowl was ok, but we did finish it all. 

I'd definitely come here again when in Vegas and looking for a meal to warm me up and highly recommend this place for ramen fans visiting the area.

Best ramen in Vegas!  I live in San Francisco and in the Bay Area we have a ton of great ramen, but I hadn't tried out the options in Vegas much until this previous trip and Ramen Sora is the real deal!  I tried the Miso Ramen and the Spicy Miso Ramen and both were delish.  I also added chasu to both b/c their chasu is ridiculously tender and tastes amazing.  Check out David N's review for more details since he goes into great detail.  The gyoza I had was great with the nicely crisp bottoms and the meat was juicy and the sauce had the perfect amount of zesty tang.  Definitely will be hitting this place up on every trip to Vegas from here on out!
I try to go to every new ramen place in town but this place is still my favorite. Love their spicy miso ramen with extra chashu.
Cute little place so you might have to wait a bit but its all good when you get your food. Very tasty and the servers are very attentive. Will surely come back again!

Awesome service, amazing flavors! I got the killer spicy ramen and the spicy pork fried rice and it was absolutely Delish!!! The Japanese lady server I think is the owner or manager she was super friendly she even packed me the spicy sesame oil Togo for my Togo fried rice I had to order one Togo it was THAT YUMMY! yes my tummy is much satisfied
Very good place. Super busy. Come in the off hours or be prepared to wait. Service can be slow, but the food is worth it if you can get off the strip. Parking sucks. If it wasn't for the ramen.......

The BEST OF BEST OF BEST curly Ramen noodle in Lasvegas! Tasty homemade Broth soup with miso & butter & corn is my favorite! Gyoza pot sticker is awesome too! Fried rice will make you cry...and fall in love....

Hard to get a table as the facility is very small so be prepared to wait as this is a popular place and not that many ramen houses around.  No frills ambiance, akin to a ramen house you'd find in Japan which is nice.  Ramen is a different style than I am used to as the noodles are thicker and not aldente.  They have a bit of a kink to them as opposed to the thin and straight ramen noodles I am used to.  They also don't have the strong egg aroma of the usual ramen house ramen.  Broth is good but there is not much else here if you arent in the mood for ramen.  Otherwise good, rumor has it the extra spicy ramen is not for those who cannot handle their spice....those who claim to tolerate hot have trouble as well - caution!

Really good ramen and coming on lunch is so much better than dinner. The last time I came for dinner the wait was almost 45 mins. This time I came on a Saturday morning around 11 and it was not empty but there wasn't a wait at all. So come early to skip the line. I love the fact when you pick spicy, you can choose from shio, shoyu, or miso. The noodles is good and the char siu is flavorful. Definitely a must when you want ramen.

I haven't had much ramen but I am happy to say that this is the best that I have ever had.  It was delicious!  Amazing flavor to everything.  It is especially good in my opinion if you order fried rice and mix it in any broth that you may have left over.  This place is very small and may require a wait but wait you must as this place is quite a treat.  As soon as i was done eating the ton of food that I ordered i wanted more, not because I was still hungry because I wasn't at all, but because it was that good.  I often find myself thinking just randomly thinking throughout the day of going back here.  I need to make it a reality again.

Broth is very good and the noodles are just right. Their service was ok, since it was lunch I didn't expect crazy fast service. The spicy meat isn't as spicy as I thought, so that was a good thing. The pork slices were so very melty. I am definitely heading back here!
just okay, the beef on my spicy ramen came out cold, miso broth was delicious with just the right amount of spiciness and flavor

What a gem! The Spicy Miso here was freaking delicious and we loved that we found this place in Vegas.
The place was not busy at all, and it's not far from the strip! 5 minutes to get delicious ramen while on a Vegas trip?? Heck yeah!

Okay okay Ramen Sora, you won over my heart and this will always be a place I stop by when I visit Las Vegas. I have also successfully converted 8 of my friends so far and they agree the ramen is pretty damn tasty.

I am from southern California where there are at least 50 ramen shop and I have to admit this is my favorite place. Here's why:

Service- there is usually a 10-15 minute wait because it is popular and good. The waiters are very nice and the food comes out in a timely manner.

Food- this is what I want to talk about. The broth is flavorful and not salty. I usually order the number one and they are generous with their meat, it comes with four pieces. The noodles are a perfect consistency. Ugh I am craving it right now as I write this.

Price-reasonable. $10 for the special which comes with seaweed, egg, mushroom, and meat. They also offer large for a dollar extra and xl for two dollars. They are pretty generous with their portions. I struggle to finish a large and I find the regular size to be perfect.

Location- off the strip in Chinatown. Looks sketch at night but you'll be alright!

I ordered the vengeful ramen.. Oops it should have come with a warning "do not get on a vehicle that has a bad bathroom for the next 18 hours". It's a double burner... Burned on the way in and burning on the way out..  That being said it was the best inferno spicy ramen I've had.    If your getting on a plane eat the spicy ramen or at least insist on a aisle seat close to the front.  Oh the 2.99 curry char siu and mango mochi were awesome

I saw the many great reviews on this location and wanted to check it out. I didn't have to wait long for a seat. We got a table for four people, as we had two more people in my group coming. The server was quick to take our order. Which consisted of two orders of very, very yummy Mochi ice cream. Only one flavor which was mango. I am a huge fan of mango so that was perfect! Then the Otsumami Platter, a combination of seared Chashu (Pork belly), Menma (Bamboo shoots) and two soft boiled eggs. The food was great, if you're not into salty foods, be warned. The meats are seasoned to perfection, however after a while, you can really taste it starting to become salty. Unfortunately we didn't get any ramen. We were still waiting for our friends. The workers were sweet about it, encouraging us, even when the two others didn't show. They allowed us to keep the table (it wasn't busy at this time) until we finally gave up on the others coming. We made sure to thank them very much for that. Great food, great staff, priceless service.

Firstly, the service is horrible.

Although the food is pretty good, the waiting staff were very rude and inefficient.  One of the waitresses had a terrible habit of slamming the utensils and food on the table, almost tossing it.  After someone in my party complained to her, she simply snickered and apologised while smirking.

The manager wasn't better at all.  He was also rude and did not take our complaints seriously.

After this encounter, I decided that was my last time going to Ramen Sora.

The Skinny: finally! a really decent ramen house in Las Vegas! I would pass on the dessert though (4) service: went during the first week of opening, a little disorganized but it's still pretty good given the Japanese efficiency (3) value: it's not bad as long as you don't order extra toppings which seem relatively pricey (4).

We came here opening week to try out their miso ramen and within a few days, we were back for more. It was really reassuring to hear a bunch of Japanese spoken in this joint by both the customers and the staff. You know that likely this stuff can't be that far from legit.

Here's the menu items we have tried so far: miso ramen, spicy miso ramen, mini chasu bowl, premium chasu side order and a order of their mochi dessert. 

Breakdown of the broths: the underlying broth has a robust, decadent pork flavour to it. Throw in the miso ($7.50) or spicy miso, you have a well balanced bowl of homey goodness. The spicy miso ($8.50) adds a judicious amount of heat to round out the taste without detracting from the underlying taste of the soup. Very subtle and well done. I think of the three broths, spicy miso might be my favourite.

The noodles are in the standard ramen style and cooked perfectly. Slightly thicker than your standard fare, I really loved the mild chewiness of the noodle which speaks to its freshness. Really, a mouth full of joy.

The egg was ramen perfection - hard boiled with a thin layer of soy permeating on the outside, a precise ratio of cooked to runny yolk on the inside. Loved it. Could have eaten at least three of those eggs alone.

If there is a weakness in the bowl, it's with the chasu. Even though the chasu does have a good texture and flavour, it could be a little bit more melt in the mouth. A little too thinly sliced for my liking, it is worth the upgrade for a few extra slices ($2) to make a more satisfying meal.

If it's your first time here, I wouldn't recommend getting a menma ramen ($8.50) or a corn/butter ramen ($9). Considering the price of these additions to the regular bowl, it's rather expensive factoring in the relative cost of the product. I mean, really, $1 for extra green onion? You can buy 3 bunches of that in the Chinese grocery store across the street. Stick to the extra chasu and maybe the tamago if you're an egg fan - you won't be disappointed.

We did try the premium chasu side order but was rather disappointed that it was served stone cold with some congealed fat on it. That certainly detracted from the texture of the product and I would not recommend ordering it.

Instead, get an side order of the mini chasu bowl ($2.85). The chasu, cut into chunks, is layered with negi (Japanese green onion) over rice with a light sprinkle of the marinating soy broth. Very stick to your ribs kind of food and highly satisfying. The chasu fared better in this instance given the way that it was served but again was not quite the perfect texture. Regardless, given the price, it's really worth a try.

Finally, the dessert. We tried their mochi balls filled with red bean and rolled in black sesame ($2). Given the great quality of the dishes here, it really fell flat in comparison. While the filling was okay, the mochi itself was overly dry. I'd pass on this menu item because there are so many other great things to fill your belly with.

Overall, I'm so happy that this place opened because we used to drive all the way out to LA to get a half-decent bowl of ramen. Now my husband can spare me the 4 hour drive there and satisfy his cravings at Ramen Sora (4).

Delicious goto! Long wait..always. Yet, it shows how good the small little Ramen joint is. Great food and top notch broth with a friendly staff. If you're into spicy ramen, then come here. The Killer spicy ramen is my top choice. Noodles of top quality with multiple broth options for anyone's preference. I eat a lot of ramen in San Francisco, and I would put this noodle shop as one of the best I have ever been to. I go every time I stay in Vegas.

If you are in Las Vegas and in the mood for a bowl of authentic ramen look no further. This ramen house is consistently on the mark. Always great customer service and usually around 11:30 am the very intimate dining room fills up. By noon there is a wait sometimes lining out the door. No matter where you sit either at  the high top communal table or the tables located around the perimeter of the restaurant you will get wonderful knowledgeable service from the wait staff. The service is super fast to take your order and deliver your bowls full of piping hot delight. They have every accompaniment you can think of to enhance your ramen experience from the holy grail of hot sauces the coveted sriracha, spices, soy sauce, green onions, and sea weed. So head over to Spring Mountain road, write your name down on the clipboard and take a seat. Wait to enjoy a delectable bowl of ramen sure to fill your belly and soul with taste and comfort you wont regret.

If you enjoy Ramen, or have always wanted to try it, Ramen Sora is a great place to go.  I am by no means an expert connoisseur, but it's the new top pick on my short list of Ramen places in Vegas.

The restaurant is cozy and bright.  It was very busy at lunch time on a Saturday(and probably always is).  I was by myself, so I was set at a big table with other single diners and couples.

I had the miso ramen and a melon cream soda.  The ramen broth was hearty and perfect.  Full of flavor, and not greasy or too thin.  They offer larger portion sizes, but the regular size was more than enough for me.  I walked out fat and happy.

As for the soda, it is better than it sounds.  I don't even like honeydew melon, but I wanted to try something different.  It was really good and refreshing.  I thought it paired really well with the taste of the ramen.  Melon and cream, who knew!?

If you find yourself in China town and want some hot, filling, well-prepared delicious food for around 10 bucks, you can't go wrong with Ramen Sora.

WOOHOO!!!
i'm such a happy camper today because today i had ramen sora and today is the day that i can say vegas actually has a good ramen joint!!!

i had the menma miso ramen and the hubby had the deluxe miso ramen.
the soup is delicious and piping hot!!!
for the hubby, it was all about the pork.
tenderoni to the max!
but, for me, it's all about the noodles.
not made in house but purchased from a place in l.a. that makes the ramen from a recipe from the original ramen sora in japan.
perfectly doughy consistency, perfectly al dente.
exactly the way authentic, japanese ramen should be.

oh, and the egg, the perfectly medium boiled egg...
mmmmm...

we also ordered the gyoza which was good but not spectacular.
the sauce they serve with the gyoza was rather delicious tho.
nice and tangy.

our server was extremely kind and knowledgeable, especially considering it was only his 2nd day of work.

finally, a ramen place i'm proud to recommend to others.
yay!!!

I'm a regular here and I love the miso! 

Prices have gone up a bit. A regular miso which used to be ~$7.00 is now $8.00. Other menu items have also been increased. 

One more downside is I feel like their portions are getting smaller and smaller. My bowl used to get filled all the way, but they've been serving less and less broth :(

We had a great time here last week and enjoyed our respective ramen bowls very much.  One guy in our small group was hesitant about trying anything "adventurous," but he was a total convert after his first few bites, finishing up not only his own ramen bowl but his wife's as well!  I had the Chashu Ramen with miso broth (3 pieces of pork) and it was delicious.  The broth wasn't too salty and the savoury flavours of the meat and noodles was a symphony in my mouth.  My friend's spicy ramen was well appreciated and it disappeared in a hurry!  Prices are reasonable (bowls are under $10) and service is fast and friendly.  The restaurant is pretty small, though, so be prepared to wait a little, and make sure your entire party is present to be seated, otherwise you will have to wait.  Reservations not accepted.

Like the Little Engine that Could, I really wanted to like this place; I really tried.  But like the Carrot Top's career in stand-up, it just didn't work.  Well, actually Carrot Top is a stretch; he just was awful.  I'd be embarrassed if I woke up as him everyday.  But hey, people know his name, so I'll give him that.

Oh yeah, the food.  I guess I was spoiled by the Ramen in LA.  NYC Ramen is pretty good.  (Man, I know that I'm gonna get some flack from some people about that comment.)  And DC Ramen is...well, where is DC Ramen.  There's like one place that I know of that serves it, and it's overrun by a bunch of wanna hipsters.

Well, the noodles were a little too hard.  It didn't seem like it was cooked enough.  The price was good though.  I will admit to that.  There's something to be said about the menu system.  There was the basic Ramen, and then there were add-ons like all places, but some certain combinations of  add-ons actually resulted in "another type of Ramen."  I felt like I was confusing the waitress by asking for the "basic" and putting in X,Y,Z add-on and it ended up being some "other Ramen" that was on the menu.

Am I making sense at all?  No?  Fine.  S'all good.  Go to LA.  If you can't, go here.

The best part about the ramen here is the broth. I really, really loved the broth-- complex and full of umami. The advertising is true! It says the broth has been boiling for a day and you can tell. Definitely go for the miso base!  The nori, egg, and bamboo shoots I got in the Deluxe Sora Ramen were delicious as well.

The noodles are good, not the best but not bad. They're a bit on the thicker side and have a great bite to them! They're also very generous with the portion.

The pork chashu is really what was disappointing. The pork pieces they gave me was basically just fat. It was really hard to eat. I wanted some pieces of leaner meat to eat with the already fatty broth, but they didn't give me any.

It gets CROWDED in here so be prepared to wait. Otherwise, staff is really nice and it's definitely worth a try if you're in Vegas.

Out of all Ramen places here in Vegas it's the top of the Top. The Chashu  "Pork" has the best Flavor this is what makes it very good. The pork fry rice is one of the best I have had. Wish they add more pork,but it's very good.
The staff is great service very happy going. The Noodle is great as well fresh...Some places I think it came from a dry pack noodle. If you love Ramen this is the place to go. Be ready to wait cause it gets packed fast.
Delicious food exceptional food especially on a cold day or for that matter any day for spicy miso soup so good  The price is right would recommend this to all my friends
I wasnt impressed with this place. Seemed cheap and grungy to me. ramen had a funny smell and taste. Had big expectations for this place but was let down

Visiting from San Diego and we stumbled upon this gem and it's has to be the best ramen i ever had. I had miso basic ramen and pork fried rice and i totally wanted seconds i can't wait to come back here. Gets pretty crowded but the turn over is pretty fast so worth waiting for (20 mins)
This style of ramen was not my taste, very blent and not fun of the egg noodle. Service was not that great either.

Well, the lines are long at times, but this is a GREAT Ramen joint! The broth is super tasty and hearty. I really like it! The noodles are not mushy. Fancy people call that al dente or something. It's a BUSY place, but the tables turn over quickly and the staff is very accommodating and friendly. My buddy told me to and an extra egg or two to balance out the carbs. He's a healthy guy and skinny. I did it. I enjoyed them a lot. If you like spicy, get the spicy meat or the extra spicy meat. Both are fantastic! You cannot go wrong with Ramen Sora!!

Quality was not great last time I was here. I got the spicy miso ramen. It came out quickly but IMO, way too quickly. The spicy meat in in the soup was still cold! It was like they literally just scooped it from the fridge and tossed it on top of the bowl like a garnish. It was still in a giant cluster when my bowl came out and I had to put it on my spoon and slice it apart with my chopsticks. Normally, I can just swish it around easily with my spoon. This cold meat totally ruined my meal. I hope it's better next time because Ramen Sora is seriously one of my fav ramen spots!

The service here is unparalleled to any other ramen joint I have eaten at in town! I am always greeted with a smile and a very friendly voice. 
  That being said, the ramen is also pretty unique in its own right. It has the spiciest ramen in town hands down ( if that is your thing) and all three broths-- miso, shoyu, and shio-- are made hot and very tasty. They don't have as many add ons to your ramen dishes as other places, but with all the essentials you can order yourself a perfect bowl of ramen. 
  My personal favorite is the large miso deluxe (which comes with everything!) The drinks and sides are all very reasonably priced, and if you want to try the gyozas here you will not regret it! 
  I have been here many times, and every time has been a great experience, whether it is to take out or dine in :)

This is my favorite ramen spot in vegas when it comes to broth and noodle consistency. They serve the thick chewy noodles that stay al dente. I always order the spicy miso add corn. Their broth is rich and flavorful which is perfect. Not too salty and just the right amount of fat. Their bamboo shoots are also super tasty. 

It does get busy here so expect to wait no matter what time you go, but you can also call in and order to go. Skip the wait in line and enjoy your bowl from the comfort of your home. I'd also recommend their pork fried rice and also the goyza if you are sharing or have extra room in your belly for some extra goodness
Best Ramen in LV that i've tasted so far. Love their Spicy Miso Ramen. Just the right flavor and spice. Friendly staff, I would def recommend my friends and family to this restaurant.

Screaming Vengeance! That's all I have to say! Ramen & spicy...SUPER spicy this is for you. I am a big spice person and this was definitely among some of the spicest I have ever had. Everything in it was mouth and eye watering. The ramen here is delicious and full of flavor. 

The menu is pretty small and really only consists of ramen choices so if your not going to eat ramen this isn't the place for you.

I must have come on a bad day as reading the reviews I really wanted to like this place. 
Me and my +2 entered the establishment. All tables were full so first thought is alright cool. This place is going to be good. 
We were seated and handed a menu, which is small but interesting. I ordered the Spicy Shoyu Ramen. 
As we were placing the drink orders we ordered 3 waters and a hot saki. This must have been inconvenient for the waitress as we only received two waters and asked 3 times for the third water. We get our food and don't see our waitress again until it comes time for the check. The ramen itself was decent, the only thing enjoyable was the spice and hard boiled egg. Other than that, the broth was a little salty. 
My waters needed to be filled, nobody asked us how the food was/if we liked it/if we needed more. By the time we were seated the business died down so I'm not to sure where our waitress went or what she was doing while we ate for 45 minutes. 
I'm not sure what was going on with the staff.

I had researched some of the top places for Ramen in Vegas.  Ramen Sora was on top of that list.  I'm not a Vegas native and was just in town, but I've eaten a lot of good ramen in my time, so I was interested to see how it's done here.

At first, the look of the spicy ramen does not look appetizing. But once you taste it, you totally forget about that.  

It's very meaty and you can fee the liquified fat in your mouth and boy does it taste good.  The egg could have used a little more marinating but it want bad.  You could tell the noodles were house made.  They tasted so fresh and so good.  Chewy just like you like in ramen noodles.

Overal, Ramen Sora is a solid choice.

I saw the talk thread on this and decided to swing by here after work for a quick dinner.  I got the spicy miso ramen bowl.  It was very tasty, but not spicy.  The ramen noodles were nicely cooked.  Very hot broth, which I hear is a requirement.  The broth was also very tasty, but fatty.  It's pork based (by boiling black pork bones, to be specific) and I could see the oil floating in it.  But that's not a bad thing.

The ramen came with two pieces of pork, an egg, green onions... there was some ginger in there... it was hard for me to identify all the goodness.  The pork was so delicious.  The egg was perfectly cooked.  The thing I like best is that it was not as salty as Monta.  I didn't wake up in the middle of the night to chug a gallon of water.  Oh, and their spoons have little notches that keep them from falling into your soup.  It's the little things that count with me.

I also tried Kurogoma dango for dessert which was mochi balls stuffed with red bean paste and rolled in black sesame.  Three for $2.  Delicious!

It was about half full when I went - pretty good for opening night.  Service was fast and friendly.  I also like their hours, 11:30am to 11:00pm everyday - very convenient and easy to remember.  It's close to my work and I like that I can get a ramen craving at 3pm and get it taken care of.

Four stars for now because they don't serve beer yet.  Ramen without beer can be a little depressing.  But they have Sapporo listed on the menu, Sapporo glasses, and Sapporo paraphernalia all over the place, so it's only just a matter of time.  Also, if my husband gives it his seal of approval, I'll bump it up - beer or no beer.  Looking forward to many visits to this great find. Thanks Mike H. for starting the talk thread on this!

Ramen is all the rage, and new Ramen-only restaurants seem to be popping up every month now in Vegas. Ramen Sora is the benchmark of this resurgence of Ramen. It is no longer just the dry brick of fried noodles you try to cram into your hotel room coffee maker.

I'll just go ahead and say it: Monta Ramen is salty. I never finish their broth, and I feel like I need to eat their noodles just to counter the salt and the odd viscosity of their soup base (too thick). Just like Pho Kim Long, Monta Ramen is the celebrity chef/critic favorite for what seems to be no valid reason. Maybe they pay their PR agencies the best - I don't know. It's 'cool' to like Monta Ramen. Well that sucks, because Ramen Sora is King. And Monta Ramen is that mean Prince who tries to trick the good Prince but ends up dying in the end trying to do so, and the crowd cheers!

At Ramen Sora I get the Nori Miso Ramen every time (w/Large Size upgrade for +$1.) There are times when I polish off 2/3rds of the broth before slurping a single noodle. It's that good. The noodles are great, but the broth is the star. Red stars unite, we have a clear Ramen winner in this town.

Warning - you may not want to eat here if you don't live in Vegas. The reason is because Ramen Sora is so freaking delicious, that when you have Ramen back home, you will be dissappointed that your local spot doesn't live up to the very high bar Ramen Sora has set.

We were passing thru Vegas on our way to Zion, and met up with a friend for dinner. He highly recommended this place, and it was obvious why. When we showed up, the place was packed and there was a 30 minute wait. 

When our table was ready, we were seated and we all ordered the Chashu Miso Ramen. When I took my first bite, I was transported to another world. The noodles had a great texture, and the broth had a very delicious and complex flavor. And the pork...Sweet baby Jesus it was out of this world. Moist, with a flavorful crust. Simply amazing.

Ramen Sora is reason enough for me to pass thru Vegas on my way to Zion in the future. In the meantime, I will try to find Ramen that is as amazing as this place closer to home.

Best. Ramen. Ever. 

I was in vegas on vacation with family and I found this place on yelp. Good reviews and location was pretty close to our hotel so we gave it a shot. Came in about an hour before closing and it was still pretty busy. Service was kind and friendly. Sat my family of 5 in about 10 minutes. The place probably isnt good for parties bigger than 6 if you want to all sit together. 

I wouldn't describe the place as small but more as intimate lol. The tables were close together but you definetly had space to eat and talk with whoever you're with without bothering other people. 

The food itself, amazing. Ah. Ma. Zing. I got the large deluxe ramen with an extra egg. I usually get tired of eating ramen by the end of the meal because I get too used to the taste but this was different. The soup was rich and the pork slices were the biggest slices I've ever seen. Just thinking abou eating the seaweed with the noodles after its been soaked with broth is making my mouth water .

I will definetly be coming back here whenever I go to Vegas.

The noodles are just different!!
 I loved it so much.

When the noodles come as I ordered the deluxe, I saw the chasu was soo thick and in my mind i said, ow, it's so thick. It must be dry n hard to chew. I dont think I'm gonna like it. I ate the first bite of the chasu. Wow!!! The chasu so soft and not even dry n hard as what I thought. 

I also ordered their chasu bowl. 
I have the same thought as i saw their chasu cut in a big chuncks of pork and the color so dark. I took the very little chunck of chasu that i could saw to give it a try. Oisy!!! Very tasty!!! It's super soft and melt in my mouth.

I missed the broth. Their pork broth is very good. I would say it similar with daikokuya. Their broth is not smell at all even though so thick of koteri.

Over all, what can you say? Ramen is all about the broth, the noodle and the chasu. This place is great!! Helping me if I'm home sick of LA's ramen.

Reviewing ramen is like reviewing burgers and pizza: It's hard to be at the top with all those contenders, so three stars is still very respectable. That's how I found ramen sora. We had a deluxe and a butter corn ramen. I appreciated the simple menu! The regular sizes were plenty big enough for us but we are not huge eaters. Everything about them was fine - the flavors, portions, just didn't excite me.

Very good service!
Very clean place,  great service and the ramen is awesome. I recommend this to anyone wanting good ramen noodles.

I finally decided too check out Ramen Sora instead of my normal go to Monta. In one of those wanted too try something new or mix it up. I had the miso ramen was very good. The broth had nice flavor too it and noodles cooked just right. Honest overall still rank Monta as the only place too go ramen in Vegas. Not that Ramen Sora is bad I will still go back feel like mixing it up or if Monta wait is too long. I love my gyoza with my ramen (tradition two together) and not notice it on the menu here plus no one compete with Monta gyoza anyway. They do have charzuka (sure spelled it wrong) bowl which I ordered like my side dish. The meat was very tasty seared on top bed of rice in small bowl. 

The waitstaff is very friendly, courtesy, and greet you right when you walk in plus throughout your meal. The restaurant not very big I though Monta was small but this place might be just as small. The parking can be hassle depending time you go. Only ten or so stalls around the back of the restaurant then you would need too park on the streets. 

Overall miso ramen was winner but still have too place Monta above but whenever need get ramen fix sure Ramen Sora on my list!

I love ramen. I just wanted to get that out there. This place is really good. I don't think I need to say much other than that. Although the two big names in ramen in Vegas is this place and Monta. I do tend to go to Monta more but I eat here more. The reason for that is Monta is always packed and I never have trouble getting seated in Ramen Sora.

I could easily eat noodles every day for the rest of my life and not get tired of them. That being said, I kind of want to LIVE at Ramen Sora. 

My choice for dinner was the miso ramen deluxe (large size, because hey, who am I trying to fool right?). The broth was divine. Such a complexity of flavor, and just enough to keep the soup-to-noodle ratio perfect. The noodles themselves were the consistency that ramen should be; slightly chewy and smooth and slurpable. The deluxe comes with charsiu, which is sweet pork. Sora's is thick-cut, very juicy and not at all dry like it is at some restaurants. Then there were pieces of nori (seaweed), menma (bamboo shoots), negi (green onion), and a boiled egg. The menu offers plain versions of the ramen dishes for those who prefer a more simplistic approach, but I enjoyed everything that was going on in that bowl. An order of gyoza accompanied my ramen, and I was completely full after that. 

Our table split the bill, and with our two large deluxe bowls, one super size deluxe bowl, and two orders of gyoza, the price came out to $15 each (including tip). Totally affordable and it sure did hit the spot. Save a table for me next time, Ramen Sora! I'll be back :)

My hubby and I tried their spicy shoyu ramen, spicy miso ramen, gyoza and pork fried rice. We are picky ramen eaters (coz we are Asian and we go to famous ramen places all the time in LA) and to our taste, they were all amazing. Came out very satisfied.

Even during the holiday season in Vegas, you won't have to wait too long to be seated if you go there a bit earlier than usual dinner time. We went around 5:45 and only waited for 5 minutes. But by the time we came out (around 6:30?) the restaurant had a long line.
Was in the mood for some ramen glad I came in.  Portions are big prices are cheap, I couldn't even finish my plate.  Place is a lil small n the wait was long but it's worth the wait.
Best spot for Ramen in Vegas! Spicy miso ramen, fried rice, and Kirin on draft. Can't beat it!

Sora is my place for the "Shio Ramen."  I've tried their Butter-Corn Ramen which is shio based soup, and it was very good and authentic Hokkaido style.  However, for their Miso Ramen, which is another traditional Sapporo (Hokkaido) style soup, I've had better ones in my days.  I can actually make a better one myself.  Cha-shu was very thick and not very tender, but it tastes good and it's homemade; so, I don't mind that.  Everyone has their own style of making cha-shu, and I have fun trying them all.  I love pork. LoL  

I also like spicy food, so, on one occasion I was brave enough to try their "Spicy Killer Ramen."  It looks awfully good in the menu, but it sounds like a soup made from habanero, so I was always reluctant to try it.  I asked the waitress how spicy it is, and she said very, very, very spicy.  'Is it more spicy than kimchee?' I asked.  She replied 'It's much, much more spicy."  So, I got the idea.  She recommended me ordering a regular size, but, I went with the large size sho-yu base.

The killer ramen came to the table, and it looks very appetizing, and it smells good.  Before I dug into it, I sipped and tasted the soup.  It was delicious!  But..., made my eyes tear.  The level of "spicy" was way off my scale.  The bad part was that it tastes good.  I thought it was their best ramen there.  I just couldn't quit!  I finished it all and drank more than a half of the soup.  The guy sitting right in front of me was just cracking up watching me tear and sweat and suffering from the torture.  Yes, I knew..., I knew I was going to regret it the next day in the bathroom.

That "Spicy Killer" probably is not your best choice to eat during the summer season.  It would probably taste even better during the winter season.  So, try if you dare. LoL

Pretty good Ramen if not a bit pricey, but still wayyyyyyyy cheaper than the strip.  Not too oily and the broth and meat were perfect.  I had the delux shio, though I was a bit bummed by the size of a standard.  I think next time, I'll get a non deluxe option and bump it up to a large for just a buck more.

Okay, I am not the ramen person in our household, but my wife and son are crazy about it, Well, I stand corrected: I LOVE ramen in Japan, especially Osaka (and even Sapporo). But ramen in the US just don't do it for me (but I'm always open to giving a new place a try). So on our one Chinatown afternoon visit in Vegas, I was outvoted from my choice of Trattoria Nakamura-Ya (well, a good excuse to go back one day soon). But I found it better than expected. The pork and broth were quite tasty and the noodles themselves had a nice texture. My wife and son both said it was good, and would happily go back (whereas for me, there's too many places I'd want to try first). We ordered the gyoza on the side, but were all disappointed (can't compare to my wife's).
Always delicious. Corn Butter Ramen with miso broth. Staff is always friendly and helpful.

This is my go to ramen place in Las Vegas. Over the many times that I have dined here, I have tried most of the ramens here. My favorite being the spicy miso. The broth is always flavorful. The spicy miso is not overly spicy. It has a nice bite to it. The chashu is not as melt in your mouth/bowl as Monta's but it isn't the main draw for me. The noodles are perfect with their slight chewiness and the nitamago yolk as always deliciously creamy.

Definitely my favorite of the ramen restaurants in town.
The killer spicy ramen is very spicy! However, it's very good. I like their deluxe miso soup too.  Also, I came here at 7pm on Friday and no line! Awesome! Service was good.

Well, where do I start? I can't say enough about this place. I have been to a couple of other Ramen places here in Vegas, which were HIGHLY recommended to us by our friends and we found them to be eh, average (so my response to that was..what was all the hype about guys?...waited in a long ass line for this?!?) And, by far Ramen Sora blows them out of the water (my opinion). My husband and I frequent this place often (sometimes date nights) along with our kids (and, will make the extra trip to bring out - of - town guests to this establishment, just so we can have an excuse to go).

We always order the Miso Ramen with curry and bean sprouts (Why fix what's not broken?)The consistency of curry makes the broth just right! Hearty and slightly thick. Just talking about this dish is making my mouth salivate. You can never go wrong with this dish! I wish I could eat ten bowls!!  So, give your other Ramen places a break and give Ramen Sora a try. You will not find fancy decor or anything flashy. You are here to eat not to gawk at patterns of wallpaper on the wall. They have a great staff - very friendly. And, the prices are reasonable.
I've been coming here for awhile and the noodles never disappoint me. Japanese noodle is something I like to eat regularly but here and there when I crave it this is the Togo spot.

Super yummy shoyu broth  ramen. Order no 1.   Not too salty . Add some white pepper and red pepper and of course gyoza. You got yourself one snappy fast meal.   Still hungry add a couple of sides or go for a super bowl for. $2 bucks ..  Free Parking nice staff.  Fast turn over.  Best OPEN Till 12pm. Can't be that

My favorite place to get ramen.  I always get the spicy miso; how hot it is seems to vary but it's always bearable.  If you're really hungry you may want to add extra chashu or get a large.  Some bowls come with more meat than others so it does depend on what you order.  

They can get very crowded and it's small inside so I wouldn't recommend going during busy hours.  For lunch, arriving around 2 pm seems to work fine.  

I wouldn't recommend taking home leftovers unless you plan to eat it near immediately.  I've taken home leftovers twice now and when I ate it the next day, not only did the broth separate (which looked disgusting), it also tasted weird.

Ramen Sora has become my go to place for Ramen. Yes, I choose Ramen Sora over Monta any day. Why? Well first even when Ramen Sora is busy you only have to wait about 20 minutes give or take a few. This is far better than Monta's wait times. Second, the atmosphere is Ramen Sora is more preferred over Monta's cramped, crowded, and extremely loud atmosphere. While at Ramen Sora I have never felt rushed and have always had friendly servers that kept my water filled and made sure I enjoyed my meal. Lastly, I have never had to play the hide and seek parking game that you have to endure when you go to Monta. Ramen Sora has plenty of parking around the back and even if that becomes full there are spaces available to park on the side street. Now as far as the ramen goes, the broth is a rich and creamy pork broth that is bursting with flavor. I always order the Miso Ramen that comes with slices of pork, bamboo shoots, and a soft boiled egg on top of a bed of noodles. Prices are fantastic here and you can always add extra toppings or supersize your bowl for only a few extra dollars. Also they have Kirin on draft for cheap! a large 24 oz is only $5. Pair your hot bowl of ramen with a large draft for an exceptional dining experience!

I really like this place better than some of the other noodle places here in Vegas. Its spacious & not as crowded as others. The soup was good, too! There wasn't anything on the menu that explained what the types of broth were so it was fun experimenting and trying different types of broths and noodles! Definitely a must-try restaurant!

Parking in the rear. Easy to get a seat. The building was obviously something else. The music was classic rock and there was a tv. Despite the weird stuff this place was great! Cheap and delicious. At the end of our delicious meal we both said that we'd still be standing in front of Monta if we hadn't come here.

The service was very attentive and they were very patient answering our questions. We had pot stickers. It came with a homemade looking sauce. It was great. I had the miso ramen, my personal favorite with extra seaweed. They put these delicious, fabulously textured slices of pork in the ramen. This pork sets them apart from other places. The broth was just as savory and buttery as I hoped. No, it surpassed my expectations, but I wasn't expecting much. They had many specials I was curious about. I need to come back.

I feel so crazy that I'm saying this, but I think I like this place more than Monta. Only things I'd want different: get rid of the tv, different music, serve beer.

we came in here for a quick bite before leaving las vegas.  i had the butter corn with shio broth. 

pretty good!

A bit salty for my taste. The curly noodles are a bit thick, but I liked the chewiness.  

Service was friendly and attentive as we visited after the lunch crowd.

I prefer the ramen at the Sawtelle district in Los Angeles J-town.
Miso ramen is my favorite. Not too salty and the noodles have just the right amount of chew. Will be going back.

I am in the infancy stages of my ramen exploration in Vegas.  While I can't say that this is the best ramen I've ever had, it is the best I've had in Vegas so far.  I always get whatever is their spiciest version of miso ramen on the menu.  To be honest, this is why they've lost a star.  It's really not that spicy.  I was expecting some major heat, but it failed to live up to its title.  Even so, I've been back twice because at least their hotter than the others. All the ingredients are fresh, and the chasu is tasty.

As for the service, I've had extremes.  The first time I went during lunch, the waitress was short with guest and didn't ever come by to refill my tea.  I had to walk to the counter and ask for more tea and water.  When I did, it turned out everyone needed more water.  She went through 2 pitchers. When I went back in the evening, it was a much better staff all around.

I'll give them 3.5 the first time and 4.5 the second time.

OH my !!!!

Glad we
Stopped in here!!
Best Ramen EVER!! 
Nice happy wait staff 
Nice ambience 
Clean
AND
THE BEST RAMEN EVER

In close vicinity to many other favorite Ramen spots, Ramen Sora stacks up well. 

As I am writing this review, a couple came in but had the leave because they found the music too loud. Funny how so many places I've visited lately repulse their customers out the door by inflicting their obnoxiously loud music on them. I won't go back to Jinya Ramen for the very reason. 

Aside from the music volume, I liked this place. The miso broth was tasty! Noodles perfectly cooked. Spice level great. 

The dining area could use a scrub down and paint job, however. Cleanliness factor is only 3 stars. I hope the kitchen is cleaner than the dining space.

This was the best ramen I've ever had. I got the spicy miso ramen and gyoza! The noodles here are my favorite ever. I want to come back soon! Everything was perfect. A bit of a wait due to our large party, but the service was not lacking. Friendly staff and good food. Best combo
Japanese Ramen house... I like it here, something different... That's why I love Vegas.... Great foodie town...

Man, I wanted to be able to say this place doesn't deserve five stars. The waitress really pissed me off. So I'm going to vent about their bullshit and then tell you how they still got five stars.

So we showed up about thirty minutes before opening and there was still a line of about 6 parties ahead of us. Now We were a group of six and there was one big party ahead of us. The rest were broken up into smaller groups. It was a Saturday so one would figure they'd have enough staffing for the rush.

Fast forward to getting seated. The host had seated the large group in their one seating area. A portion of the restaurant was blocked off because apparently they couldn't handle it due to limitations on staff. Pairs were seated in areas that could have easily turned into 4, 6, and 8 tops but because of the odd distribution of parties, there were no tables to combine without moving folks. They split us into a party of four and two. We did say that was okay.

When we sat, asked the folks at the table next to us if it would be a big deal if we switched our two for the two of them. They were very quick to oblige. It wasn't that long after we sat down that this happened, we hadn't even ordered.

So we called the waitress over who proceeded to chew us out and say that it would be "too complicated" for the kitchen and that they wouldn't allow it. 

Look, I get it. It doesn't make life easy when people like us do that. We could have just said we would wait longer for a large table (it would have been an additional 20-30 minutes based off of how long the big table moved out). What pissed me off was the rudeness and the fact that they could have avoided this situation with proper staffing. At a Japanese restaurant no less. I expect more from them.

I think I could just stop my review here. I mean, they pissed me off and I'm still giving FIVE stars. The ramen is that good. It's a hearty, rich tonkotsu broth. The noodles are a little thicker (not Hakata style) and have a nice chewiness to them. Great job on the eggs, the chashu is amazing. Gyoza and fried rice both complimented the ramen. Trust me, it's good.

Here's an insider tip though. As a man who loves miso ramen... order it with butter. It goes really well. But this is my trick. Instead of completely mixing it into the broth, I wrap the butter with the hot noodles. This allows you to have the broth plain to start and then you can pull from the noodles when you want the buttery flavor. As you get further in, it becomes richer.

It may sound crazy but believe me, it's flippin' delicious.

Cheers!

I've only tried one more ramen place in Las Vegas, and this one was by far way better. I got the spicy miso ramen, not amazing but not bad. I feel that the broth needs to be spicier, but that's just me being not picky.

The long wait made me think yum, but the end result was anything but. :(  

I tried 2 things on the menu. Maybe I need to try more to learn what all the hubbub is about.

Ramen sora is the best. I personally think it is way better than Monta.
Unlike Monta, Sora is bigger so you get seated faster and because it is bigger you don't feel as uncomfortable as you would in Monta.


I usually get the Chasu ramen with a miso broth but lately it has made me full really quickly.
So now I get the Chasu ramen with shio base and it is so good. The taste of the broth is really good and it doesn't make me as full fast.
Also if you want a nice refreshing drink from here I suggest the Melon Cream Soda.
I'm not exactly sure how to describe the taste, but to me it taste like honey dew in soda form and it's super yummy and refreshing.

I haven't been here for a hot minute but we came here for a quick lunch so I thought I would update my review... STILL DA BOMB!! Shoyu Deluxe was ordered by both of us. Broth is rich and flavorful and the pork is like MELT IN YOUR MOUTH BUTTER SON!!!  SOOOO freakin' DELICIOUS! NOM NOM NOMMMMM!

Probably one of the best ramen spots in town! I ordered the deluxe ramen sora with butter and corn. The noodles are thick and the broth was amazing. The wait time for a table was about 10 minutes and the wait for our food was short as well. I'd recommend this place to anybody who wants ramen

I came here when they first opened and the food was quite tasty.

The ramen was good - great flavors with not too overpowering saltiness.  One bowl, and I was completely satisfied.  

The service here was good as well.  I came here during the not too busy hours, so we were served quickly.

At the end, I did get a dessert of Kurogoma dango - I especially liked this during the meal.  It had a crunchy outside and sticky-sweet mochi texture - which was scrumptious.  I'd definitely come back for this, but wished the serving size wasn't so miniscule.

This place is BOMB. I'm obsessed w the ramen here. I usually always get the super size and  usually never end up finishing it, lol but it's so good that I can't stop eating. I get the miso soup and add corn and butter which makes it that much more creamier. If you haven't tried ramen definitely try it here.
I had the large soy ramen and it was very good. I think it taste better that Monta Ramen. Different but better. Will be back for the Miso version.

I go through Ramen-loving periods in my life...often in the winter.  More recently I have been on a hiatus however because I had some incredible Ramen in So-Cal a while back.  That hiatus came to a crashing end when I finally followed the advice of Yuhi K. and Ashley S. and gave Ramen Sora a try.

I had the Miso Ramen, but also tried my sister's Shoyu.  They were both good, but the Miso is definitely where it's at!  They are also super easy and economical to customize...large size, extra meat, seaweed sheets...etc.

I also recommend the mini chashu...nice grilled flavors with a solid sweet soy glaze! 

I wish they were open late...I would love to stop in after a night on the town.  There is also not a lot of seating, so peak times can bring a wait with them.
Had the shoyu broth deluxe ramen. the broth was ridiculous! you should definitely stop by next time you are in Vegas.

Came here on Wednesday afternoon,  wait time was around 20 - 30 minutes.   Ordered special sora ramen and spicy ramen.  Food was relatively decent.  For some reason my special sora ramen was a little salty compared to what I am used to.   Servers were super nice and helpful.   Crowd there is mainly young people and atmosphere was casual.   Parking is limited so maybe look for street parking.  Price is around $8-$10 per bowl.   Not a bad place to check out if craving for ramen when visiting Las Vegas.  Pretty good choice for lunch on a cold day.

I seriously loved the ramen more than most places. The miso broth is pretty thick and flavorful, one might consider it a meal on its own. I ordered the super size sora bowl with a mini pork bowl for a side. All together this meal ranged about $15. 

First the ramen was a curlier type noodle that most ramen spots do not use but i absolutely loved it. The curls gave this texture to the bite that made every mouthful a pleasant. The fatty pork belly literally melted off the cutlet into strips which made it easy to grab and boy was the meat soooo flavorful, i haven't had such good pork in ramen in quite some time. the veggies that came in my bowl were perfectly matched and accompanied the authentic ramen very well.

the mini bowl was $2 and had loads of meat in it. I really cant stress enough how much food you get for the price, not to mention the taste. I really like this spot and is the best when you're near.

if you're in Las Vegas gambling please take a break and come here.
Not that many options on the menu, but I got the corn butter ramen real delicious. Very friendly and nice ambiance
If you like spice and can handle HOT ontop of spicy.. you must order the killer spicey ramen w/ miso..it was very good!! i cant wait to go back and try the other ramen, and their curry.
Excellent service every time I come. Always delicious and my favorite option in Vegas for ramen

Traditional Japanese setting with modern day pop music playing. Medium-sized space. Ordered deluxe sora ramen. Broth was good. Pork was lean and moist at the same time. You also get more meat than at other places. Better than what I have found in West LA. Really huge portion. I had to kill myself to finish it.

Came here for lunch on Thursday March 24th with a friend. We both got sick later that night, but I was violently ill for 3 days. I've been here a few times before without incident but after this last experience I will not be returning.
Best miso ramen I have tasted... Chashu melts in your mouth and the gyoza?! Delicious :) Vegas visit is not complete without Ramen Sora meal!

A solid ramen restaurant, but the menu is kind of basic. The soup was good, but there wasn't a lot to choose from on the menu. They do a great job with what they make but other ramen places in town have a lot more on the menu.

This was my first time trying ramen and I'm so glad my cousin brought us here. We were a bigger party (8) so we had to wait. The place is compact a lot of small tables. There was only on table that could fit us all and so we had to wait. I will for sure comeback before I leave. After waiting about 45 minutes we got seated and ordered our food. Then menu is small but there are different sizes of bowls. Regular, Large $1 extra, and Supersize $2 extra. I got the Chasu miso soup base regular. There are 3 different soup bases. Miso, Shoyu, and Shio. The order didn't take long to come out and felt really good to eat this warm soup in this cold weather, aside from the wait because we were a bigger table I can't wait to be back.

Excellent Ramen, much more enjoyable than Monta.  

Friendly staff, fast service.  Broth was richer and tastier than Monta while being less salty, and the squarish (cross-section) curly noodles I found much better than the round, straight noodles at Monta.

I am a ramen enthusiast...my ramen quest has taken me all over the SF Bay area and every city I visit, and this would easily make it into the top 10. Maybe even top 5.  Not quite at the same level as Ramen Dojo (San Mateo) or Orenchi (Santa Clara) but much better than I expected to find in Vegas.

Kudos Sora!

I think they have changed the chef or ownership. Totally nothing compared to a year ago. Reman blend. Broth super salty. Eggs cooked. Meat dry. No wonder no Japanese/ Asian customers anymore. Should alert myself when I see no lines during weekend lunch hours. Go mento if u want reman. Good luck!

I'm always on the lookout for good ramen spots. I tried Monta Ramen on my last trip and wasn't rushing to go back.  Happy to say that Ramen Sora didn't disappoint.  We arrived shortly after they opened and the line of people started as soon as we were seated.  Score!  I tried the regular sized Deluxe Sora Ramen with a miso base, $10.  The portions were bigger than I expected.  I'm in love with the chewy WAVY noodles!!!  Rarely do ramen places serve wavy noodles.  The chasu could be more tender but they give a lot of it!  I counted four pieces!  The broth was good but a tad salty.  I wish the egg was a bit more runny... it was still good. The hubs commented that the price is steep but I think it's more than reasonable.  Most ramen places charge extra for most toppings.  At Ramen Sora, the Deluxe Sora Ramen came with everything I listed above in addition to green onions, three large pieces of seaweed, and bamboo!  I think it's a steal.  The hubs was sweating from the Screaming for Vengeance ramen, $10.  I tried it and it was very spicy!  But I think my spice level has gone down.  He said he wouldn't order it again though, haha.  Not because it wasn't good but because it made him very uncomfortable and sweaty =D Biggest gripe is that I wish they offer a tonkotsu base broth.

Awesome ramen goodness with some nice prefixed selections such as the screaming for vengeance or the deluxe sora. My only gripe was even after ordering the xl I wanted to get some more noodles when I finished my initial noodles and you can only add more at the beginning kind of a bummer l.  Other than that fantastic broth and noodles not as chewy as I like but won't stop me from coming back.
This was my first visit to Sora and was not disappointed!! Delicious, chewy noodles and tender pork made the bowls some of the best I've had. We will definitely be back!!

My brother and cousin told me that Monta is the best Ramen is Vegas so I drove by this place numerous times.  Problem with Monta is that they are so small that you could wait an hour before getting a table.  So I came here instead.  What I found out was a much larger place, but again, very minimal tables so the wait can be as long too.  Today, though, I had no wait.  After eating hear, I will have to challenge my brother and cousin that this place is just a good, if not slightly better.
Probably our favorite ramen place in Vegas. Small so depending on the day can get busy but its YUM!!

By far the worse ramen I have ever had. I have had some amazing ramen in other cities and I was really looking forward to trying this one. I can say that I will never be back. The quality of the noodle was no different than what you get at a store when you buy NISSIN TOP RAMEN and the flavor of the broth seemed to be made from powder concentrate. 
The service however was outstanding. The hostess and waitress were extremely friendly.

I decided to stop by here after a friend of mine said that someone from Ichiza said this place was better than... well, better than the ramen house that seems to have started a new ramen trend in this town.  As the long time (until recently) duke, they've set a gold standard for me, and so for the purposes of this review, I will be calling them "the other ramen place".  You all know what I'm talking about anyway.  This review is a comparison review.  Sorry, but it's the only way I know to review a ramen joint at this time, and Ramen Sora holds it's own!

The building is a lot more spacious than the other ramen place.  It's more comfortable.    There's also not a 15 minute wait.  In this case, that's a good thing.  Like the other ramen place, service is fast, friendly, and professional.

I ordered the spicy miso with extra chashu.  The broth was very flavorful!  Much more savory than the other ramen place.  A lot less salty.  The spiciness had only a little kick (I eat a lot of very hot Thai food though), but it was enough to give a well rounded flavor to this thick, tasty broth.  If you have a problem with the salt levels of the other ramen place, this might be your go to restaurant.  The noodles were better, I thought.  They were thicker, and "meatier".  Very well prepared.  The chashu was tender as if it had been soaking in broth all day.  It fell apart in my chopsticks.  Yum.  The chashu slices were a little thicker than the other ramen place, although perhaps not quite as tender.  

I may dare to say that the overall quality of the ingredients is a little higher here than the other ramen place.  It definitely has a more bold flavor profile, at least in the miso.  I love both places, really, which should say a lot about Ramen Sora.  The bottom line here is that Ramen Sora has added a new flavor to this town, and it is worth while to check out.  It may not become your favorite ramen house in town, but I think it is definitely a great addition.  Thank you, Ramen Sora!

Some of the best ramen I"ve had. Went there on a Monday night and there was a 40min or so wait but much worth it.

Had the killer spicy miso and it was actually pretty spicy and damn good. Good chaisu , not too lean. Its been a month and a half so I dont remember how the gyoza were but I think they were good.

Compared to east coast prices this place was dirt cheap, both the base ramen and the add-ons. 

Good food, good service, good prices.  Solid.
Not vegan friendly. All ramen is pork based broth. Just a heads up since I 'yelped' vegan friendly restaurants. Otherwise, the place was packed and the staff was friendly.
Sora outshines Monta any day! Don't even waste your time with other ramen places. Just come here.
Best chashu pork and gyoza!!! Great service. Can't wait to come back

Chashu was thicker and leaner compared to all the Ramen places that I have tried.
Noodles are cooked perfectly.
Food was served quickly.
I love all the side dishes.
Tasty pork fried rice ang gyozas.
Egg was very much flavored.
Clean.
Do you like SPICY ramen? Killer Spicy Ramen IF you dare.

Spicy ramen and 6 pieces of seaweed as an extra topping for a dollar more was such a good lunch! 

Their noodles are soft and not chewy. The egg was not salty and tasty. My soup was not really spicy for a spicy ramen but I tried my friends super spicy and it tasted spicy. Their slice of pork was perfect and so was their ground beef. 

I was debating if I should have ordered the large bowl but after finishing the regular, I was full and happy.
My friends were happy we found this small place in Chinatown.

Craving ramen in Vegas?  Look no further, this place is good.  Very tasty broth, moist and tender chashu, spicy miso has a good kick and if you need more spice, the killer spicy meat is a good add.  This place and Monta are my favorite ramen places in Vegas.  Both are small though, but we've never had a problem getting a table.

Have eaten here twice now, out of 1-10 Its an 11. Delicious, Delicious, Delish,  
Always a little wait, but soooo worth it! Meat is soooo tender and fresh.

Lots of parking
Small restaurant.
Parties of 4 are probably best.

We had the Deluxe Sora Ramen (my wife loved it) and the Spicy Miso Ramen (i thought it was really good but I could have gone for some more heat).

Next time I'm going to try the Spicy Killer Ramen (waitress told me it has Habanero in it)

By far the most annoying and worse experience in my life.. when it comes to restaurant..!! Me and my Husband loves ramen.. its sunday afternoon, and we decided me and my family to have Ramen for lunch.. we waited about 30min to get seated... and this young lady who wanted us to seat by the bar.. and we told her we have kid we wanted to get seated on table.. and she rolled her eye on us..sign that shes look annoyed by us.! Ive work in restaurant bussiness too.. im not asking for a great service on this kinda small place, but have some kinda idea not to neglect your customer.!! And when we wave at her, to ask her if we can get someone to take our order,!  and we told her that after we waited 30min to get seated and we waited again for another 25min.. and that time, i loose it.!!!  I have enough of it..! That we wanted just to leave the place..and before i left the restaurant,i spoke to this Lady and ask her whats her name.,and she reply why.!?? I told her she have a bad attitude and bad service.!! I wanted to talk to managment before i leave.. and Ms, Sunny, i guess the manager or owner, and she nicely apologize with me for what happen and to her server staff attitude..! Over all, i would not ever, ever step on this place ever again..nor recommend this place..Even if you have the most delish ramen on planet.! If you have bad service and dont know how to take care of your guess.. u be in the list on most worst restaurant in vegas.!! Btw Atlease Monta ramen take your order quick..!! once you sat down after you waited for long time.. not in here...
This is my favorite ramen place in Vegas! Their broths aren't as salty as other ramen places and the prices are good too for the amount you get :)

I think I've got a new winner.  Let's face it, it's all about the noodles and theirs edges out Monta's by a hair.   I had the spicy miso with extra chasu, because who doesn't love extra helping of fatty pork.  The broth had a nice flavor but a little on the greasy side, edge Monta.  All in all, a good meal with a friendly staff.  Misses are the small menu.  Which isn't a big deal in Asia, but westerners generally prefer more variety. Secondly, the broth was a hair on the greasy side.

CONDENSED IN A SOUP CAN: 
     It boils down to personal preference. Sapporo peeps will love Ramen Sora for its chewy noodles and its seasoned miso broth.  And though this goes against the general tide, I'd have to say I am a Kyushu or Kurume sistah.  
 
THE MEAT: 
    There are a couple of popular types of Japanese Ramen named after their region/city of origin, 2 of which are now big players in the Vegas scene - Kyushu, or more specifically Kurume ramen (served in Monta Ramen) and Sapporo (served in Ramen Sora).  There are differences in the preparation and quality of broth and noodles, but both places offer the same general toppings - thin slices of roasted pork, egg, green onion, corn and bamboo shoots or wood ear mushroom.
     I can't give a review of Ramen Sora without comparing it to Monta Ramen, which was my first love.  The noodles are curly and chewier, and although I liked the soft thin strands of Monta, I enjoyed the bite of Sora very much.  The Sora miso broth is generously seasoned, and I believe the red specks are Togarashi, red pepper flakes that are available on your table - it has a very distinct flavor, somewhat smoky and a tad tangy.  The Sora broth was more complex, and maybe I'll like it more once I am accustomed to it.  
     For now, the foodie prude in me misses the conservative broth in Monta, rich in meat and egg flavors... and though the broth may get cloying, I love the no fuss straight up lard goodness. All in all, both ramens rock, and will cure any hangover and hit your spot. 

I'M STILL DIGESTING...
     How some folks expect a toddler to go out of their way instead of them accommodating a 2 year old.  Which do you think is the easier task?

WANT TO SEE SOME FOOD PORN? :-)
Miso Ramen http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-sora-las-vegas?select=EdGuA5w5Rx8Z6FY_SiWXkA#EdGuA5w5Rx8Z6FY_SiWXkA
Mini Chashu Pork Bowl http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-sora-las-vegas?select=EdGuA5w5Rx8Z6FY_SiWXkA#iW3taw4-XhN5FeYhhmUzaA
Gyoza http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-sora-las-vegas?select=EdGuA5w5Rx8Z6FY_SiWXkA#v0v__nlCEH8S44oSjZFBXA

The venue is small but the atmosphere of the restaurant is laid back and fun! Perfect for a first date or a night out with friends. 

I had the Killer Ramen with extra pork belly, extra egg, and seaweed! Super spicy but oh so yummy! 

Also, i reccomend you get the gyozas because they pair so well with the ramen. Its almost harmoneous! 

Definitely coming back again!

Ramen Sora is the BEST RAMEN NOODLE in LASVEGAS more than MONTA noodle shop. As a native japanese, my tongue is picky, their noodle really made me addicted !!! Soup Broth is handmade soup & curly chewy ramen noodle are the Best !!! I usually get Corn Miso Butter ramen noodle there ! Shoyu, shio, miso, spicy one, all of them are great !!! Dont forget to eat their HOUSE FRIED RICE with ramen !! their fried rice is out of this world !!! I am in love with their noodle! Chef is from Tokyo & Osaka japan !!! One of the best source of japanese food !!!   Address is :  4490 Spring Mountain Rd, Las Vegas, NV 89102   (702) 685-1011

This place is absolutely amazing!!! Yummmmmmm very tasty and will have you craving for it the next day !! Waitresses are soooo nice and always full of energy ! Was in there where the stage inspectors went in, and everything was perfect :)
My second favorite ramen place in Vegas. The broth is a little light, so I always ask for the shio base. It's always so tasty and I can't wait to visit my family in Vegas so I can go back.
Seared pork belly is a must try! Good charcoal flavor. Gyoza was good. Extra spicy ramen is a real challenge! Spicy level was 9/10. Very good ramen in town.

This is one of my favorite places for ramen. The Killer Spicy Ramen is worth a try if you're daring. The service is good, and even though the dining area is small, the food more than makes up for it. As for the sides, you can never go wrong with the gyoza, and be sure to look at the extras menu to make your bowl unique to you!

Mediocre service, but the food came out fast. The food was too salty for my taste and it didn't settle too well in my stomach. It gave me a stomach ache right after and I felt very lethargic. It was ok, but I will not be coming back. Had better in California.

This place has completely soared. I'm happy for them, I really am. It wasn't as crowded a short while back, but now you gotta wait a while to get your hearty bowl of ramen. There isn't much seating, but the ramen does indeed come out fast, and the service is speedy.

I had the spicy miso ramen, super bowl was big enough to share with my mother. The chashu was super tender and the best part of the whole bowl. The broth itself was good. I wouldn't consider it spicy at all. I wasn't kicked by it one bit. The noodles were "al dente" as my mother would call it, and their noodles are allegedly handmade so I gotta give them props for that. Other than that, the dish wasn't the best ramen I've had - but it was tasty, nevertheless.

As for the Gyoza, I hate to say it but it was one of the worst gyoza's I've had. I starred at the gyoza and wondered if it was homemade or if it came out of a shirakiku frozen package. Don't waste your time with these dumplings. They're not known for it anyway.

All in all, a great ramen experience. I would DEFINITELY come here for the noodles, but it isn't worth the wait.

I went here with my cousin after a week of expensive fine dining at Mandalay Bay, and I couldn't be happier. Great ramen is heavenly, and Ramen Sora did not disappoint. I ordered the spicy ramen with shoyu broth. The broth had depth and wasn't too salty, the noodles were chewy and toothsome (perfect), the pork chashu was tender and flavorful on its own, and the spicy ground beef mixture added texture as well as a good kick to the ramen.

The seared chashu is amazing. The noodles are my favorite. I've been to at least ten ramen joints in the valley, and this one is my favorite. Do yourself a favor and get the seared premium chashu and the chashu ramen. I get it with out mushrooms and egg. My SO likes it that way also. However she prefers the thin noodles and I prefer the thick. This place is a must.

Second time here! Ordered something different this time, just to try something new! But wasnt as good as the first time I was there. Overall soup base is very flavorful, noodles are good, and the variety they have. Staff are very friendly and welcoming! Always coming by to check on each tables. Make sure to go early ish on weekends as there can be a wait. Its not a really large place.

Perfect authentic japanese ramen place a little ways off the strip. Service is relatively quick, but the place tends to get busy. You know a place is good and worth it if the locals are eating there. I will be back again very soon!

I ordered the miso ramen which was a good portion size.

The only negatives were probably the gyoza and the fried rice. Not bad, but nothing spectacular. I expected a bit more from them, as it is a small Ma and Pa restaurant.

My manager brought this to work and it looked and smelled amazing! After asking him, he gave me the name and I headed over with my family two days later. The place was small, but it was super packed! The wait was maybe 10 minutes so we ordered a couple of beers while we waited. Ordered the spiciest ramen (warning it's a punch in the face kind of spicy) and two of the shio base regular ramen. It was SO good, also order the garlic edamame if you get the chance! Friendly service, great ambiance, and mostly importantly, good food.

My favorite is the chashu ramen. This is the second time we came here, we waited 2 mins at 8 pm on a monday. (The first time we waited for 30 mins). Small seating but very cute environment. I would def come back and eat here.

Before I give you my opinion about Ramen Sora, let me give you some insite into Japanese ramen. There are many different styles of ramen in Japan just like there are many different styles of pizza in America! Many people I speak with will say that Monta Ramen is way better than Ramen Sora. However, that's an unfair judgement because they are different styles and come from different regions of Japan. Ramen Sora reflects more of a Northern Japanese style ramen using miso, shio, or soyu broth with thicker noodles. The ramen you get at Monta is a tonkotsu style which is a richer pork broth generally using thinner noodles. 

With that said, Ramen Sora is pretty good when it comes to their ramen. I would recommend the Miso out of all the broths as it tastes rich with flavor. 

The reason I gave them 4/5 stars instead of 5/5 is because I feel that their chashu pork fall a little short. Japanese ramen style chashu takes a lot of skill to prepare correctly. If it's done right, it should just melt in your mouth. Ramen Sora's chashu is very tender but i'd say it fall behind Monta's chashu. A few reasons why I think their chashu is not perfect is because they do not roll their slab of pork belly when preparing it. This causes more moisture to escape from the pork during the cooking process. You'll notice Monta's pork is rolled and melts in your mouth. 

So all in all I give Ramen Sora a 4/5. Not bad for ramen found in desert!..and incase you were wondering, yes I am Japanese! Happy Eating Folks!

You can't compare Monta and Sora. They are two different beasts.

Me? I'm a Sora fan. I love getting the chasu ramen with miso broth and extra noodles. The Sapporo style ramen noodle is slightly thick, curly and complements the fatty broth well. Since the noodles are slightly curly more of the broth coats the noodle. This makes for a fun splurpfest. 

If you come on a weeknight or after 6:40pm, be prepared to wait 20 minutes.

We come here at least once a week. The best ramen I have ever had. Pork is so well cooked and tastes like perfection. We always get the shoyu base which is tasty and always hits the spot. Great place for take out or eat in! Highly recommend!!!

Picked this place to go to last minute and definitely was surprised. Their chashu and gyoza were suuuuuper bomb af. Would've kept getting more if i wasn't going to be late for my flight. Would come back again if I could!

Went there after much encouragement and was pleased with the food.  The service is quick and efficient.  Everyone there is after a good meal and waiting is not uncommon.  I ordered the No. 1 and it was delicious.  The pork and miso base really tasted good and would be perfect after one of our windy days in Vegas.  The gyoza was hot with a bit of crispyness on the edges but very flavorful.  Overall I'd come again.

I used to go to Monta for my ramen fix when I'm in Vegas, but after trying out this place, I started going here instead. I always get the spicy miso ramen. The broth is super flavorful. They have a killer spicy hot ramen for people who love spicy - that is too much for me. This place gets packed fast so it's best if you go right when they open or late in the afternoon. The servers are friendly and attentive. I would highly recommend this place for ramen!

Legit best miso ramen I've ever had. As rich and creamy as any good tonkotsu ramen. Very delicious. And for only $2 extra, you can make it an extra large portion. Definitely a must try if your are a ramen lover.

YES.... definitely coming back.

I came here on a weeknight with a group of friends (4 total), and was seated after a short, 5 minute wait.

Sora Ramen with Miso broth:  One of my friends has a theory that when a restaurant has a dish with it's name in it, you have to try it at least once.  I did, and I'm glad.  I never had Sapporo-style noodles prior to coming here... and I am hooked!  I love the fact that you can get Nori style, with giant nori sheets added to your ramen!

Chashu was cooked well. Fatty, melt in your mouth and delicious.  I'm not typically a fan of boiled eggs, but this one was soft boiled to PERFECTION.  

Vegas has definitely raised the bar for my ramen tastes. I will be coming back here... without a doubt!

People will argue there are better ramen destinations, but I'll have to disagree every time. The ramen here is so full of flavor! Their chashu here is alway meaty and not mostly fat like some places.
