You can order a larger size of the ramen which is significantly more for only $1.00!

I do like ordering it to go and enjoying it at home more. But, the ambience inside is wonderful as well. It's really small and personal. The service can be slow sometimes but, whenever they are helping you, there is always a genuine smile on their faces. 

Team Sora!!

One of my favorite ramens in Vegas. Their miso broth is so flavorful and rich. It's perfect on a cold day. Their thick noodles are doughy and perfectly Al dente and the chashu is thick and tender. Add the spicy meat of you like spice. I'm going to try the 'killer spicy' next time :)

We have been coming here for years!! One of the best Ramen in town!!

Melon Soda 
No.1

The butter ramen was soo good it melted in my mouth and I wanted more!  I would get it with the shoyu broth! 

Hard to say if they are better than Monta.  I'd say pretty equal.

Very worth a stop if you are in the mood for some hot and delicious soup. The service is amazing and the staff are very helpful. It's been a while since I have been to a ramen restaurant and this place didn't disappoint. My wife chose the miso. I thought it was amazing. But it wasn't really her cup of tea (or soup in this case). She was happy to eat the chashu on rice. With the smokey flavor and sweetness of the sauce it was a hit. I got the crazy hot shoyu ramen with extra nori. I love to eat habanero regularly so wasn't expecting it to be too spicy, once again not disappointed. The heat started just right and I was soon tearing up by the end. We got some edamame two soups some appetizers and left paying less than 35 dollars. It was fun. And despite the dislike of miso for my wife, she even said she would come back.
Great ramen with a good variety of Japanese food, portions are fairly size able w/ good taste. What I like about this place is the portions are great for the price.

Ordered the miso chasu ramen with extra bamboo shoots. Broth was rich and flavorful and NOT super salty.  Unlike the ramen I tried in Fukumimi. The true seller here is the chasu. The slices of chasu are super thick and tender. I've never had a ramen that had such thick slices of chasu, you definitely get your money's worth. Also I'm in love with the bamboo shoots. I like how they are thick, chewy, and juicy. The way they're supposed to be eaten! Most ramen places give very thin slices of bamboo. The ramen noodles tasted ok, they were also thick and wavy, nothing too special about them. I'd wish they offer chili oil on the side,  it would've made the broth even more awesome. They do have chili powder, however I find it doesn't really offer much of a difference in flavor.  

The only downside to this place is how crowded this place can get. Seating is limited. We came around 3pm, it got packed fast. Another downside is how stuffy and hot inside it was. I was sweating in there! I'd wish they turn on the AC full blast or something. Eating hot bowls of ramen especially in Vegas weather, not very comfortable. Parking was plentiful though. I would definitely come here again if I ever have an urge for ramen again. The quantity and quality of the chasu and bamboo shoots definitely won me over for sure.

I had Ramen Sora for the first time last night and I was not impressed. We only came here because I wanted to taste it so I could compare it to all the other ramen joints and also because we figured it would have the least amount of wait time out of all ramen places.. 
We still had to wait about 20-30 minutes.. Even though there were tables available. 

We had an order of gyoza and the deluxe miso ramen & deluxe shio ramen.. 
The gyoza was not good to me it had a weird almost iodine taste to it.. 
The miso broth was nice.. very deep and creamy..way better than any other miso broth I've tasted.. also I did like the chashu.. very melt in your mouth good and they don't skimp out on it in their deluxe ramen..  I liked the chewy consistency of the noodles but personally, I am more of a fan of thinner noodles.. My ramen also had that same weird taste to it.. I think it was the taste of the menma.. So I must not like the taste of their bamboo... & The tamago didn't really have any seasoned taste to it..
The service was not good at all.. Our waitress never checked up on us.. She never even refilled my water. BOO!

So as of now Ramen Sora is at the bottom of my list~ Sorry SORA, My cousin's name is Sora, HAHA but you need to step up your game. ;ppp

If I come back here I will probably get the miso ramen with no menma & no tamago but with extra chashu and hopefully the service will be better~!!!

Idk why i only gave a 4 star. I love Ramen Sora. Love the ramen, love the chashu bow, love the spicy pork fried rice and love the environment and employees. Always busy but they're quick to bring the food out. My fave ramen spot in Vegas! 5 star all day!

This is probably the best ramen I've ever had in my life, but don't take that too seriously as I've only eaten at a total of three ramen-ya in my life, not counting the 19-cent packages from the grocery store.  The first time I came here almost a year ago, it was forgettable. I don't remember liking it or hating it. But I tried it again a week ago and it was Fan-effin-tastic.  I was blown away.

My friend and I tried to go to Monta for lunch, but the line was crazy-long so we hurried over to Sora.  There was a line here as well, but not as long.  We waited 30 minutes and finally got seated.  I have to say, the servers and hostesses are impressive the way they turn the tables over.  They are quick and do not waste a single minute getting people in and out of there, and yet we never felt rushed.  

We both ordered the spicy ramen with shoyu broth. I added nigori and extra chashu.  The flavors were amazing.  I could not believe how much I loved this bowl of ramen.  I've alway been a huge fan of Monta but I'm afraid to say I will probably never go back to Monta after having eaten this bowl of delicious spicy ramen.
The place is kinda small but very good RAMEN!
A secret of Las Vegas when it comes to ramen. The ramen here is one of the best you can find in Vegas and I highly recommend trying the spicy meat :)

Ramen Sora is hands down the best ramen house in the Las Vegas valley. I've tried all the other ramen places, most of which are much pricier than Ramen Sora, and have not found a place that came close. I usually order the Miso Ramen or Deluxe SORA Ramen with the miso base... and the flavor of the broth hits the spot every. single. time. The selections here are super affordable & have generous portion sizes.

One down side is that this place is tiny and is ALWAYS poppin. So if you come on a busy time, expect to be waiting for a while. The parking lot is also tiny but there are residential areas around you can park at. This is so worth the wait and I always look forward to coming back when I'm home, whether it's 115 or 50 degrees out.

Pretty darn tasty!

1.  The soup - I really love the light flavor of the soup. I can tell that it is just like homemade, boiled for a long time with all the bones and pork and etc. Light, subtle and very tasty.

2  The Ramen - Just right Al Dente

3.  The choices -  All sorts of choices, additional toppings, larger size with more noodles and etc.

4.  The key points - I like the pork tenderloin in any ramen. I also like the flavor of green onion sliced and cooked to perfection. 

5.  Parking - Has parking, in it's own lot, however, the traffic direction seems to be a bit odd, seems that the entrance is two way, yet large enough for only one car.

6.  Service and Seating - Small, be prepared to wait, nice service, and very busy.

For a Ramen place, very nice. I have been to many Ramen shops in Japan and in San Francisco, so having this place as an option is nice.

GK says, check it out.

By far the best local Ramen shop I've been to. Never bland and the noodles are on point. There is usually always a wait time so it's best to go during the slower hours. Screaming Vengeance is spicy good. I always get added on items, making my total to be $14 for a huge ramen bowl. Worth every penny.

I would say after trying all other places, this is it....their soup base and meat are perfect..prices are better than other place, service on par..week day lunch time is always full, but it sits way comfortable than Monta, the noise level will get pretty loud when it is full though.

My 2nd visit here in a week.

So I was there about 12:15pm, and the parking lot was 75% full.  Fortunately I was able to be seated with no waiting, but the place was pretty much full.

This time, I tried Spicy Shio with extra green onions and gyoza.  

Gyoza:  pretty good.  But I would have to give this gyoza battle to Monta.  It's very possible they Sora will get better as they have been open only a week, but Monta's gyoza had more flavor and juice.  

Shio ramen:  I'm not a big fan of shio ramen, but I have to admit that this was pretty good.  simple, not oily, with some of the tonkotsu flavor coming through.  Spicy Shio is a weird concept as it makes it somewhat spicier and fattier, which is somewhat like ordering a veggie burger with extra cheese.  I  think I'd stick with Miso personally, but I do like their noodle.  Al dente, slightly chewier than Monta's miso ramen noodle, and wavier.   I think  it is more like a traditional miso ramen noodle from sapporo.  People who are not fond of heavy, kotteri type broth will probably prefer shio ramen.  Not me.  

Service:  today they had a one Chinese lady waiting the table, and other two were Japanese.  This is somewhat disappointing for an authentic ramen house, but it's not that big of a deal as the menu is short and simple.  However, the service seemed to be faster today.  Perhaps they are getting used to it after the opening week.  

As I was leaving, there were a few people waiting to be seated and the parking lot was full.  There is plenty of space to put in a few tables, and I really think that they need a counter space as all authentic ramen houses should have.  I'm just surprised at how quickly the word has spread and so many people have discovered this place.  

It's hard to say who is better:  monta vs Sora, but I'd go to Monta if I"m feeling for tonkotsu, and Sora if I'm in the mood for miso.  

There are no other Japanese ramen house that come close to these two.  If you disagree, please keep going to the place where you get served by faux anime characters.

Pretty good but I guess I'm just a Monta girl. I prefer everything about Monta's ramen. I haven't tried anything else at Sora except for their ramen. I ordered the Miso Ramen this time. It came with one piece of cha-siu thick cut. I prefer Monta's thin cut. Sora gives you half an egg where as at monta you would have to pay extra but Sora's prices are a bit more than Monta's so there's that. Also, Sora is more spacious and bigger. The parking is a lot better since they have their own parking. Can't go wrong at either place.

The menu may be a bit limited but the food is amazing! And the service is amazing. You know a place is great when the water tastes good! I've been here a couple times and I only get the *Basic Miso Ramen* because you can never go wrong with some miso.

This place is pretty new, so they don't really have any decorations up or have a liquor license (they are working on it).  the ramen is pretty good.  They don't have shoyu ramen.  They have siro or miso.  I tried both and liked it.  It's worth to go back to again to try different items.  
Although, my favorite ramen place is anime ramen!
Excellent service. Very plesant. Ordered the deluxe with super size.. so far best ramen i tried in las vegas. Atmosphere is very relaxing..

I debated which ramen-ery to (re)visit while in Vegas. I opted for Sora because it's conveniently located off the strip in Chinatown and near a bunch of boba shops.

A few highlights:
- I REALLY loved my bowl at Sora. Great noodles, amazing broth, the best part was three huge slices of fatty pork belly. Hard to compare with Monta because I tried Monta last year, but I think I preferred the deluxe over Monta's tonkatsu which was a little too rich for me. 
- Sora's seats more than Monta, but the wait is comparable for a weekday lunch (~15 min). 
- Service wasn't the best, and didn't appreciate smokers by the front door and lack of ventilation, but overall I would definitely come back!

My  favorite place of my family's ! We even order out when out of town guests come in. Fast friendly service and best ramen noodles hands down in Las Vegas. The restaurant is a little small and they do get packed on any given night of the week, but I guess less overhead keeps the prices affordable! Two of us can eat here for roughly under $25 bucks

I've been eating a lot of ramen these days and Ramen Sora is just one of the places that I happened to check out. I've been there twice so far, but this review is a reflection of my most recent visit.

We arrived on a Sunday evening and the restaurant was not full at all.  There were plenty of empty and cleared tables available.  However, they insisted that we write our name down and wait.  A few more parties arrived after us and they were also instructed to write their name down on the growing list.  (Hmmm...why can't they just seat us?  Don't they see that we have a toddler in hand who is attempting to touch all the business cards and paper junk they have at the front register while we wait?  We could entertain him a lot better if we were seated!)  I could only assume it's because they are understaffed.  Are they hiring?  If not, they should be.

When we were finally seated, putting our order in takes a good while too.  Be prepared to wait!  But when you do get your order in, it comes out super fast!  So, that's definitely a plus!

We ordered the Nori Ramen - Miso ($8.50) and the Butter Corn Ramen - Shio ($9.00) and upgraded the latter to the larger size ($1.00).  We thought the ramen was fine, although the Husband preferred the broth at another ramen joint we had just visited the day before out of state.

On our first visit, we also tried the Mini Pork Chashu Bowl ($2.85).  It's a cute little tiny bowl that is very kid-size friendly or an add-on to your ramen bowl.

3.5 stars

Finally a good ramen shop in Las Vegas!

I've been to every Japanese style restaurant that serves ramen in this town from junk (Anime Ramen is just so gross) and the Ramen Yokohama Kaigenro use to have. Right now this is by far my favorite ramen that I can get in Las Vegas. This place has the best ramen, seriously. Great portions and for a $1 more you can get a large size that goes a long way in the end. 
Things I would recommend to anyone are :
Curry Bowl
Chashu bowl
Gyoza
Shio Ramen
Miso Ramen

Though to be honest with everyone, I would stay away from the fried rice. It's very bland and a little greasy .

In the opening week I went here twice, so this place is going to become a regular spot for this ramen fanatic.

I've been to both Monta and Sora, and I have to say that Sora is the better one of the two! Sorry Monta, but you don't have as much variety and space compared to your rival. 

The corn butter ramen with miso base is the best! Adding the butter makes the broth more creamy less thin, and it tasted like heaven! I was skeptical at first and thought they were crazy for adding such a big chunk of butter, but I was wrong! 

Service was great, because we came in during their slow hours and there was no wait. Our server constantly refilled our waters and checked up on us. The only bad thing was that they didn't give back our change after we payed the check. Even if it was just a dollar and something cents, I would have liked for them to give us back our change instead of assuming that they could keep it. Customers usually leave the tip on the table after they give back change!

I'm sorry to say this, but I was very unimpressed with this place. I had high hopes as my parents have gone here a few times and told me great things so I was somewhat looking forward to trying the ramen. When I did finally try Ramen Sora, I ordered the Miso Ramen, gyoza and pork fried rice. The gyoza was gyoza - it's hard to mess that up - so I enjoyed it. I really liked the pork fried rice, so kudos for that, but when my miso ramen came out... man, what a disappointment. I liked the noodles in it, the pork belly was cooked well, but the flavor of the bamboo shoots ruined the whole thing. I don't know if they didn't boil them to remove the rancid smell/taste, but it completely ruined my ramen experience. The broth tasted like the shoots too, after I had removed them from the dish. I just couldn't eat past the flavor and normally bamboo shoots are my favorite.

Who knows, maybe it's a regional preference of that flavor that I'm not familiar with because everyone else in the restaurant seemed to enjoy their yucky bamboo infested broth and ramen, but I am not a fan, so unfortunately, I will not be returning here for my ramen needs.

Ok so i have been to: shuseki, Monta Ramen, Anime Ramen, Ichiza, Oronchu ramen in LA another place deemed the best in San Diego none of them even come close to this place. Their ramen is hands down the best for me, everyone that I have brought there has always left saying the same thing, I just hope they don't get busier because of this awesome post :) i love it there. This is my configuration there: Large Miso Menma ramen with bean sprouts and curry in the bowl, you will love this configuration. Also need to have a large Kirin beer there nom nom nom....

My boyfriend had recently introduced me to this place and I was hesitant on trying it. I had always chosen Jinya as my go-to ramen place. 

I had gotten the basic Miso Ramen and when it first came out I was blown away at the portion. It is a very generous portion for the price. The broth warmed me up from the inside out and the noodles were al dente. 

We had also gotten the gyoza which was delicious as well. 

Fast forward a week later, we go back again and we both get the Chashu Bowl and it is massive! For around $8 we got a bowl we could hardly finish. The pork was covered with some type of soy based teriyaki sauce and over rice. Everything mixed together was delicious but a little too salty. 

Definitely a place to go if you want something that will fill you up and inexpensive.

Came to Vegas and was in search of some great morning after ramen! found this placed and checked it out, it looks a little sketchy from the parking lot but the place and employees are inviting! This place had some of the best spicy ramen I have had the pleasure of eating!
Spicy miso ramen was my favorite..  I also ordered the pork curry rice bowl but it was a bit too salty for my taste.

We've never had Ramen before unless you consider Top Ramen to be ramen at all. 

Arrived just before 5p.m on a Monday and were seated right away! 

Per waitresses suggestion we ordered a Miso Ramen with extra green onion and corn. 

Oh, WOW! Soft boiled egg was just perfect! Oodles of Noodles done al dente, pork belly surprisingly tender, broth is rich and has the slightest after-burn. Mmm-SOOO-good!

Next time we'll try the Shoyu version...

We are absolutely STUFFED!

Don't bother reading because once you're hooked you're going to need a family intervention, 3 months of rehab and 5 years of regular therapy just to get off of the sweet nectar that is the Deluxe Ramen Sora in miso. 

Also, the fried rice is severely underrated. Get the spicy one. It all goes great with a pitcher of Kirin.
What can I say, I love this place, my go to is the chashu shio with killer spicy meat, and can't get enough of that pork fried rice, let's not forget the curry, and dat pork, soooo good
Spicy miso ramen with butter. Enough said. This place is small and authentic. Best ramen in town hands down. Their gyoza sauce is also delicious!
Love this hot spicy soup!!! Yummy!!!  The service is great and the host was very  attentive. The noodles are amazing!!

3 different soup bases; I went with the Miso.
3 different sizes; regular, large, super size, I went with the super size
Loads of extra toppings; I always get an extra egg, and if I am really hungry, extra bamboo and chasu (pork), I just chose the extra egg (Tamago).
My bowl doesn't look that much bigger than a regular or large, but don't underestimate the size as they fill it up with lots and lots of noodles and broth. I went with the spicy ramen which isn't super spicy but still held a nice kick, for the really spicy go-getters, they have killer spicy.
Great service, restaurant isn't extraordinarily big, but they accommodated 12 of us no problem.

Went with a big group for a friend's birthday.  We didn't make a reservation but put ourselves on the list around 6pm.  There was a little bit of a wait because the place was small but not too bad.  Parking can be hard too because their lot is on the smaller side.  I think it might be the smallest lot I've seen in Vegas for restaurants haha.  Service was good.  They brought us water and menus right away.

I ordered their special ramen.  A lot of my friends got it in a large because it was only 2 dollars more and the bowl is a lot bigger.  I was happy with mine though because I barely finished it.  The ramen was good.  Noodles were nice and soft and the broth was thick.  Not as rich and flavorful as I hoped it would be but it was decent.  Lacked some level of rick pork flavor though.  I don't want to give it a low review but I just think that i've had much better elsewhere.  This palce is really just OK with me.  This is my first time having ramen in Vegas...so I can't really say how this compares to other local spots.  Maybe after i try other places I'll update my review since i'll have a better comparison.

Beer is a good deal at this place...I think a pitcher is for 11 bucks?  We ordered 2 and had a great time.  We didn't order much appetitzers except the gyoza.  It was yummy...like all the other restaurants hahha.  Crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside.  I tried my friend's spicy ramen and it wasn't too bad.  They just add some spice to the miso paste.  The spicy ground beef was good but wasn't too spicy either.  I usually order no spice with my ramen because I love the rich flavor of the pork broth but since the broth wasn't spectacular, I asked for chili oil to make it better.

I would definitely go back to this place again and give other ramen places a try but if every place in vegas is like this..i don't think I'll be craving ramen all that much.

The gf and I were exploring the Chinatown area.  We'd had our banh mi appetizer and decided to find some ramen for our lunch main course.  Once again, we referenced our Yelp iPhone app and two names seemed to be head and shoulders above the competition, Monta Ramen and Ramen Sora, based on the sage advice of Misti Y, Janel S, and Yuhi K.  We made our way up W. Spring Mountain and Ramen Sora became our default choice since it was a shorter walk from Mr. Sandwich. 

Ramen Sora doesn't look like much from the outside or inside with its dive-ish exterior and generic furnishings, but it definitely sounds like a Japanese ramen shop with the shouted greeting "Irrasshaimase!" as you enter the place and the slurping of noodles and broth.  The menu is pretty straightforward with descriptive photos of items offered.  While the Spicy Miso Ramen sounded intriguing, I went with the regular Miso Ramen with Chashu ($9) since I had recently had a similar bowl of miso ramen at ramen shop in DC from which to base a comparison with Ramen Sora's.   Three thick slices of pork belly rested atop a bed of nicely cooked noodles, which were bathed in a generously-sized bowl filled with flavorful, but not too salty, miso broth.  The broth was a bit greasy, but it was a result of the fatty pork belly, and not a detractor from the overall bowl.  Ramen Sora's Miso Ramen with Chashu was not quite as good as the bowl I had at DC's Toki Underground (http://www.yelp.com/biz/toki-underground-washington#hrid:J5z59CPghtxPxofmaWWhdw/src:self.), but it was appreciably less expensive and offered incredible value!  Ramen Sora really delivered!  Next time, I'll have to try the Spicy Miso Ramen.
Awesome Ramen!!! I get ramen everywhere I go, it's a tradition.  Did not disappoint, 2nd best I've had only to Ippudo in NYC
Miso Ramen is my fav. Gyoza is good. Just tried the Charsui Curry Bowl - wow that was great! Oishi! As soon as they open it fills up. The service is great and fast. Will definitely be back!

Ramen when it's 97 degrees outside?  Absolutely!  This place is the "nuts".  I'm almost against writing another good review, as when I was there earlier today there was about 15 minute wait.  

Good thing service is fast and friendly.  While you are waiting check out there big poster with instructions on how to order, choose broth type, bowl size, and any extras.  

I'll be back!

Ramen Sora is my number one go to ramen establishment. There is always a long wait but is worth it every time because of the crazy customer base.... But who would blame them... This is definitely the number one ramen spot in Las Vegas. The prices are amazing and the food comes out in a fast and timely manner. Their chashu is very good as well as the egg that's added in the ramen! I will be back :)

I have been coming here every single time I am in Vegas. I once waited by myself for around one hour just to eat here. 

I always order the miso ramen soup.  The other day I ordered fried rice to go and both the soup and the rice were both delicious! While I haven't really tried the other broths, the miso one they have which I guess is as close to tonkotsu as it can be is 10/10.  

My only suggestion would be to improve their eggs. While I had never had any problems before, the last time I was there, the egg was slightly overcooked.

If you are in a hurry, you can call ahead and order food for pick up. They are super efficient btw.

I've been wanting to try this place but since the other ramen place had overly salty broth the last two times, I got turned off eating ramen all together. There was a odd day of constant rain and cool temps in this blister which needed to be celebrated with some soup. Made for a perfect excuse to have something warming.

I grabbed up a miso ramen and the BF went for spicy ramen and on the recommendation of the server for a "lighter" broth got shoyu base. The miso was savory and buttery (has some oil floaties, but enough to be a deterrent) and not overtly salty. I really like that it comes with a soft boiled soy egg, the thicker rustic roast style cut of chashu was tender and the ramen was rightfully chewy. This is a bit different from the traditional Sapporo toppings I'm used to as it normally has corn, bean sprouts, pork, and garlic. I suppose I could add those toppings next time. I took a taste of the BFs shoyu spicy broth and it was fairly good. Still a bit porky, but much lighter since it isn't creamy like the miso and the spicy crept up to a medium burn. 

We got a mini chashu bowl to share. It was much smokier than the chashu in the soup so it seems they throw it on the grill before serving and top with a drizzle of sweet soy so it's a different experience. I like this preparation. I wish they offer some vinegar as a side condiment as the little bit of acid would be nice with the sweet. 

We came within the last hour of being open so I figured that's why service is quick, but hope that it soup comes out that fast regularly. Our server was friendly and didn't make us feel rushed. 

I definitely prefer this over the other ramen place. Somehow my BF got it in his head he doesn't like ramen so even though I like it, it may be a trek I make again alone.

I don't know what it is, maybe I'm just not a soup lover. Or maybe I'm actually really picky! I wasn't really blown away by Ramen Sora, but I did have a pretty good experience! 

Ambiance: 3 - I like the casualness of the place, and how it looks like an actual ramen joint! There's not much seating, it can probably seat 30-35 people at a time. It is plain and clean, but not very interesting inside. 

Service: 5 - Loved the service and our server! It was a nice change to see someone who wasn't Asian serving at an Asian ramen place! He was actually really helpful and really kind. They were fast at bringing our food out and filling our water. They are always checking on you and always available to service you!  

Food: 4 - I liked it, but I didn't like it. Just like I said earlier, I feel that I'm pretty picky about the soup I slurp! The one thing that I really enjoyed is that every order, though it might have the same soup base, has a completely different flavor, which I really enjoyed! Because of this, I can't say that there was a favorite or a soup that was better above all the rest, because they are all tasty/interesting on equal levels. 

I just can't recommend one, so my advice would be to close your eyes, spin around, and point your finger at the menu! If you're a soup lover, you'll probably enjoy the flavor no matter what you choose!!
Not the best ramen I've had, but its still pretty good. The prices are comparable to any other ramen place.Would recommend!

Probably the best ramen that I've had in Las Vegas. The broth is made from a base added to a pork bone broth that the brew for hours & hours. You can get a variety of different soups.

I like the charsiu ramen with killer spicy meat and corn. That was perfectly spicy. The heat tends to come with what tasted like Thai chilies. Obviously not something I thought I'd find in a traditional Japanese dish, however, it was good & I LOVE Thai chilies, so no complaints here. The noodles had a nice bite to them. And the pork was rather tender and savory.

The service was friendly and accommodating to my rowdy yet fun group of friends. We left them a very nice tip for their troubles, because we did feel they earned it. I think most of the guys wanna make this the "last stop before skipping town" on Vegas trips from now on. Great after a night of partying.
Fantastic!! Love the Ramen! There's definitely a wait but worth it. Get the Gyoza and Miso Ramen. I get the Spicy Miso Ramen with extra bamboo shoots. Yummmmy!!

This place is awesome! Ordered the miso deluxe with a side of spicy pork rice. The spicy rice was had great flavors and well balanced. The miso ramen has a rich deep flavor. One of the best ramen shops I've been too. Highly recommended

What did you eat in Vegas? Ramen!!! One of the best things to get after a long night of drinking on the strip is a hot bowl of delicious ramen. Ramen Sora has what it takes to satisfy that craving! We came on a Friday afternoon and there was no wait. 

We ordered their deluxe sora ramen with miso broth and it was so GOOD. The broth is hot and rich in miso flavor, but it's not your regular store bought miso flavor! Sora's miso broth has depth and a fatty pork richness flavor as well. The noodles are chewy and thick. It's the perfect consistency that I love in ramen noodles. It went very well with the rich miso broth. The charshu pieces were thick and flavorful. It has a very nice charred flavor. The seaweed and bamboo pieces were all great. 

The only thing that could be better is their soft-boiled egg and the broth gets too salty after several slurps. My egg was a bit overcooked. 

Other than that, this place was awesome! $10 for a delicious bowl of awesome ramen. It can't get any better than that!

BEST RAMEN IN LAS VEGAS. BEST RAMEN IN LAS VEGAS. BEST RAMEN IN LAS VEGAS. Did I brain wash you yet? 

This place is seriously good. Every component in my bowl of ramen is above par. The broth...hooomaigoshhh. They do miso justice here.  I always get the spicy miso and it's perfect. The right amount heat...dangerous, but enjoyable. *rawr* (last time I checked there is an exxxtra spicy version too, for those who can handle the heat!) The right amount of salt...this is super important because there is that fine line between bland and too salty.  Noodles are thick, wavy and al dente, never ever soggy! Last but not least, the Pi-chashu...I choose you!  *giggle* Ramen Sora makes the best chashu. I don't know how they do it, but no other place can compare. The slice of pork is meaty, lean with less fat, fall apart tender, and oh so tasty. *note: it only comes with one piece* I totally regret not ordering extra chashu. 

It's officially fall in Las Vegas. I can wear boots and scarves without feeling silly. Naturally, I'll be drawn to eating more ramen this time of year.  There's just something about ramen that warms the soul. Looking to try the deluxe ramen next :)

I've tried many ramen places and by far this one is my favorite. Would recommend it to anyone. The price is fantastic, some of the ramen already come with the add ons unlike other places you have to pay for every add on. The service is great very fast and super nice! I will definitely come back when I go to Vegas again.

Consistently outstanding Sapporo ramen 5200 miles from the source! (If it doesn't sound far think of it as a minimum of two layovers and 16 hours flying.  Bam!)

Sora is simplicity at its best:

- One bowl of perfectly cooked, slightly chewy ramen.

- Two choices of  flavorful broth (salt or miso).

- Three topping combinations:  basic (excellent chashu, soft boiled egg, and veg), Sapporo  (basic plus butter and corn),  or "American"  (basic with three times more chashu and/or nori).  

- Like it spicy?  Add a Thai garlic chili paste.

- Sides?  OK fried rice, OK chashu bits on rice, OK curry on rice, Good but oily gyoza. (NO TONKATSU)

Efficient service.  It's Japanese fast food after all.

Pushing the limit for Vegas cheap eats at around $9.00 a bowl but well worth it for the quality and uniqueness.  Try it soon.  It might not be so great when its 110 outside.

Wow, this place gives Monta a good run for it's money.  First thing you will notice is the pork in ramen is the softest that I've ever had.

Their miso broth is very rich and full of flavor, you gotta believe it when they post on a sign that they cook this overnight.

The noodles are thick and chewy, cooked to perfection.

I ordered my deluxe with miso and extra noodles for $11, it's a pretty good deal in my book.  Note that I came at 3PM, completely off hours and it's decently busy.  Expect a long wait for prime time.

Oh how my opinions have changed. Over the past 6 months or so, I'm finding myself craving Sora over Monta. I must have had a bad bowl the first time I dined here because every bowl after that has been ramen perfection.

As always, I continue to order only the miso ramen. Shoyu just doesn't do it for me. The miso broth here is rich and flavorful. And that creaminess that I used to get at Monta is no more and has found itself in my bowl of Sora Ramen noodles. The noodles here are special too as they are thicker and chewier than those skinny, limp noodles elsewhere. If you generally prefer an al dente noodle, these will be right up your alley.

After living in Vegas my whole life, I've come to appreciate the fast life. And by fast life, I mean little to no wait-times. In the 24/7 city, things are done in the moment. And when you're stomach is about it eat itself after a long day of work, you want a quick bite to eat--not a 40-minute wait to eat 15 minutes worth of food. Sora has a relatively large, spacious dining room which allows them to serve more people in shorter time. Summation: Little to no wait times.

Location  |  Not that this should be a huge factor considering its only 1 block closer to the strip... But Sora is 1 block closer to the strip. If you're coming down Spring Mountain, a bowl of noodles at Sora is 2 minutes closer to you than Monta. Just saying.

Battle of the Ramen(s) has officially come to a close and I'm pleased to say Sora is #1.

If there is a ramen god, they dwell in this place. 

I've been wanting to try this place out since my cousin came to visit. They were here for a week and went there almost every day. Now I see and taste why. 

This is a tiny joint on Spring Mountain in the heart of Chinatown. Don't ever under-estimate places that aren't the "highest rated". This place was the best I've had by far. From the broth to the toppings; everything was amazing. 

I had the Miso broth - chasu ramen and I had them add extra chasu. Horrible idea because I was crazy full. Which I didn't even care at that point because it was so freaking delicious. 

Love this place and I can't wait to bring my momma there.

This is my favorite ramen place to eat. In two weeks my bf and I  tried 4 different places & this by far was our top favorite one. We went twice the same day we found out about this place. 
Staff is friendly and welcoming. 
Food... ahh! It's delicious. Just go! 
Spicy Ramen is my favorite.

Favorite ramen place in Vegas! Big pieces of chasu, flavorful eggs and perfectly cooked ramen noodles! My entire party ordered the miso flavored soup base and we all loved our meal. I ordered a side of spicy meat added in my soup and it was a little too spicy for me, even though I normally can eat spicy. Also, the meat was cold, but warmed up after I stirred it into my ramen. We also ordered two orders of gyoza for our party of 4, which we ate quickly. We went around 4 pm on a weekday and the restaurant was empty, I was expecting a wait so I recommend going during that time for minimal waiting. Highly recommend this spot for flavorful ramen.

Craved ramen during our vacation & went here for lunch. Yelper's suggestions did not disappoint. The food was delicious & service was friendly. The place is pretty small & gets packed during lunch & dinner hours, but it's worth the wait. Boyfriend had the Spicy Miso & I had the Deluxe Sora Ramen which were both rich & satisfying. The noodles were perfect. We also ordered a side of the Pork Fried Rice, Gyoza & Extra's platter which had menma, chashu & boiled eggs. Definitely will go back when we're in LV again.

My wife and I had the spicy miso ramen (not the crazy hot one) which was perfect for us. My wife also ordered the melon soda which I would definitely recommend. I would say about a 5 out of 10 on the heat scale. The chashu was a little salty for me but the noodles had a good texture and the broth flavorful. We arrived about 1pm on a Sunday and were seated right away, but shortly after the restaurant filled up.
This is a great ramen place in Las Vegas Chinatown. If you're a fan of ramen and have a craving while in Vegas, go here!

Ok, so I know my first review was harsh...but I was mad at the time.  Maybe I should remove it...but maybe not. Anyways...

Finally got around to giving Sora another try!  We had a much smaller party, and came during the day, so getting an immediate table was easy.  (This was my issue last time around).

Started off with some pork on rice :

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-sora-las-vegas?userid=eZZyuJDouIg4p-GYB3PV_A#VkgcZaYqSkhBws2i-R_dnA

And then ordered their Deluxe Sora Ramen at a $10 price tag...it was a little spendy, but there was a large portion sitting in front of me, and lots of pork and goodies inside.  It was very good...noodles a little thicker and broth a little saltier, but good nonetheless.  Probably my second favorite in town so far :

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-sora-las-vegas?userid=eZZyuJDouIg4p-GYB3PV_A#7kcOrxTs-DRWz0CllfQHDw

Also ordered the EXTRA spicy ramen....and it was HOT!  They don't hold back...it was delicious, but it was spicy!

It is really hard to compare ramen vs ramen since they have different ways of creating the magic inside your bowl, but since it is essentially similar overall, this is my 2nd favorite of the "big three" in town.

I'll be back!  /Arnold Schwarzenegger

I just want to say that I have been here about 3 times in the past couple of weeks. For a busy college student, that's a lot! I have been totally addicted to their miso ramen, and I always order extra chashu now. It's deliciousness never fails me. 

Yesterday I decided to try their gyoza, and boy was it delicious! It was the perfect combination of crunchy and chewy, and on top of that..perfectly seasoned! We have a goal to try all the side dishes next time we go, so expect an update soon.

This place was pretty good. I got the spicy miso Ramen, which was quite delicious. The soup/broth was so good I finished that before the Ramen. The staff was extremely friendly and prompt. Also, the have canned sodas which is minor to some but I love that fact. Lastly, the serving sizes are massive, a regular was huge to me. All positive vibes here.

Today is raining outside, the floor in the dining is pretty slippery and there is no warning sign. I'm 36 weeks pregnant, at the moment I entered I almost fell down , luckily my husband was behind me and held me. And no one even asked if I was fine or not!they just pretend not see this happened! And the food is shitty! This is my first Yelp review and I wrote it out of anger!
Not a bad ramen place to try. So try it if you haven't! The people there are friendly and the ramen is pretty good.

TERRIBLE SERVICE BEWARE!!!
The food was alright tasted decent. My biggest problem was the service! I felt as if they were purposely ignoring my boyfriend and I. We came in waited about 7 min to get seated which is absurd! Then it took them a good 10 min to even take our order! There were others around us who have received better service! I've asked all three women working as servers for a refill on our water. LOL its a fucking joke! To have the women go around the entire restaurant filling up everyone elses glasses but ours. I've asked for my check TWICE! They never handed it to us. We had to physically walk to the counter to pay unlike every other individuals who it was just handed to them. People may argue that we were perhaps rude or disrespectful during our visit, but I guarantee you we sat there enjoying our ramen. 
If I could give this restaurant zero stars I'd love to! First and last visit. I didn't even leave a tip. Just gave them an exact amount.

Love this place! It's one of the few places where I will wait an hour for a table. It's a tiny total hole-in-the-wall in Vegas' China Town, but it's so good! Once you are seated, service is attentive and fast. I ALWAYS order a deluxe large ramen with light miso broth, an extra egg, extra chashu pork, and extra green onions. Sometimes I add a side order of curry sauce to my soup when I'm in the mood for it. I practically eat here every day when visiting Vegad, because I haven't been able to find ramen as good in the bay area. To avoid a long wait, try it out for lunch or go for an early dinner (before 6pm).

To me this is what good ramen is! Absolutely love the portion sizes and the taste of their miso broth. I will usually get a regular sized bowl and then another one to go before I leave so I can have some later that night =D. I know, I'm a fatty.

Got the Chashu Shio Ramen for the extra pork and it was tasty.  Also got to taste the Miso soup base and although good, it was a little salty for me.  The noodles were very good and had that chewiness or "bite" that ramen lovers look for.  Will definitely be back next time I'm in Vegas.

So delicious, I'm in love! I've actually never been a big fan of Ramen - I prefer Pho or Bun Bo Hue (guess I'm a little biased). But, this place is soo good!

We went here on Saturday night and there was a wait, probably about 30 minutes? Once we were seated, service was quick and friendly. Most of our party ordered the Butter Ramen, but I opted for the Chashu Miso Ramen - the pieces of pork were so soft and melted in my mouth and my bowl came with 3 pieces of Chashu.

My boyfriend got the Spicy Miso Ramen which came with one piece of meat and he preferred mine - just due to how delicious the Chashu was. We'll be back soon!
One of the best ramens I had.  Screaming for vengeance is spicy and very good.  Friendly sraff.

My favorite ramen place in vegas, delicious every time. I always get the miso ramen and never disappointed.
I have also ordered take out from here and they package it very well. It is also large portions.

A solid 4 stars.  The ramen is very consistent every time I eat here.  And always delicious!

I would give 5 stars if they gave 2 pieces of char siu instead of 1.  One piece is not quite enough, and to order 3 more pieces is too much for me to eat.  I'm a fan of the shoyu broth.  I've tried the miso, but I don't like miso soup so shoyu all the way.  Regular size is good for a petite person like myself.

Finally got the chance to try Ramen Sora on our last Vegas trip, and sooooo glad we did! I was debating between Sora and Monta, but after seeing several Monta reviews about its saltines, we opted for Sora, and boy are we glad we did.  We got the shio ramen and man oh man, it was goooood!!!  I'd compare it to Santouka in Los Angeles. Yep, that good. I think I actually like Ramen Sora a tad bit more than Santouka (I know I know, heresy!). Prices are very very reasonable and service was quick and efficient. We got there on a Monday night around 4:30PM and there were already about 6 groups in line, but the wait went quickly. 

The husband got the chashu ramen and I got the deluxe, both shio broth.  Both were excellent, but mine was better because it had more toppings. The gyoza was the one thing that was a let down, because it tasted like the generic frozen type they just fried up, so skip that. Also got an order of the grilled chashu, because we love love love the grilled chashu at Hachi. While Sora's wasn't bad, Hachi has the edge because of the charcoal-grilling.

Sora was so good that we ordered two large shio ramen and the pork fried rice to go, which we had for dinner Tues. night when we got home. Can't wait to go back!
A must stop if you love ramen. You can choose your soup base, add extra toppings, and spice it up.  Stop searching, and stop on by.

In Battle Ramen, generally I am the loser. I have insisted for months, perhaps even years, that I just don't get ramen. In Battle Ramen Vegas, the contenders are widely considered Monta and Ramen. I am no ramen expert, but I have learned that these spots serve up different types of ramen (Hakata vs Sapporo). Some contend they should not be compared, but if thin crust vs deep dish is a fair fight, so is Hakata vs Sapporo. 

And, the winner for me is the Sapporo-style delight being served at Ramen Sora! I would actually return for more, please. 

I ordered the Nori Ramen with miso broth. (Based on my rapid Wiki education, miso broth is the signature broth of Sapporo-style.) I passed off my egg to my husband and removed all of the bamboo shoots, and from there on out, it was edible bliss even on a 103 degree day. I rarely finish an entire bowl of soup, but I slurped every last drop of the rich, flavorful broth. I also devoured the curly, slightly chewy noodles. I was even a little sad when I finished off the last bite of pork. It wasn't too fatty, and it had the taste of the finest pork BBQ in Texas. Oh, and I have recently developed cravings for seaweed, so the crunchy sheets lining the bowl were a wonderful treat. Alas, it was gone too soon.

I also enjoyed the atmosphere. It is clean, airy and cool. There are numerous seating options, and the service is super quick.   

Like pizza, I think that ramen is probably a strong personal preference, but personally, I haven't had a finer bowl of soup than this miso broth beauty in quite some time.

Random notes: They have alcohol-free Sapporo beer, and for all you spicy lovers, they have a Killer Spicy Ramen which we heard is pretty insurmontable.

This place rocked. Doesn't look like much from the outside,it's a small place. We arrived early and they were still closed. Right before they opened people started to fill the parking area so we hurried up to the door. We were about 4th in line and we got seated in the first rush of people. The ramen was relatively fast for being so packed! There was still a line out the door as we left,It was our first time here but it was awesome!

THE miso broth!!!! Sooo good and the pork chashu is like crack, I mean I could eat the pork for all three meals. The service is always good and the greeting you get just gets your mouth watering the goodbye is hard to understand because I can't hear very well by then cause I'm feeling like I'm drugged with happiness. This place is seriously my top three places to eat not just in the valley but anywhere just by judging the food alone.  The only downside is the size and the location no special scenery or anything. It would be an honor to have a bowl of this ramen as my last meal.

It's a small space, about 8 tables and then 1 long table that can hold about 10 people. 

We were craving noodles and was going to have pho but my little guy said let's try spicy ramen. We ordered their signature ramen noodles. You cannot go wrong here the pork just melts in your mouth. And the soup is perfect amount of flavoring and spice. We would definitely come back here again especially since our 11yr old actually likes it, yes he found something other thing chicken he will eat!

I'll readily admit, I'm a ramen noob.  
I've been to one other ramen house, exactly one week ago. 

Saturday night, after moving  friends all day in the heat, my fella and I decided that we wanted to give Ramen Sora a go.  

We drove over, and there was a bit of a line, but the wait wasn't bad at all.  
The restaurant is open, and spacious, but has an intimate feel.  

The server was super nice, taking time to explain the differences between the broths to us.  

We ended up ordering an appetizer "sampler" of the flavored egg, bamboo shoots, and seared pork belly.  We also ordered gyoza. 

First of all, I have to toot my own horn: I successfully ate my egg with chopsticks.  On the first try.  :D    The egg was delicious:  with the yolk just a tiny bit under hard boiled.  (Solid, but not dry). I loved the bamboo shoots, but was nervous about the pork belly, and almost didn't try it.  I'm SO glad I did!  It was smokey, and tender, and juicy...really delicious. 

Our ramen arrived next:  Mine was the shoyu (soy based) with corn.  Morgan had the shio (salt based)  They were phenomenal.  I loved mine so much, I actually drank all of the broth.  

I loved the service, and how polite everyone was.  

So...for the rest of the night and all day yesterday, Morgan was talking about Ramen Sora.

I started feeling really under the weather yesterday, and felt just as bad this morning...and the only thing that got me out of bed was a trip back to Ramen Sora with friends!

We got to try the miso broth this time, as a friend ordered it...it was awesome.  SO rich!!

Service was spectacular, and the food was just as delicious as it was Saturday night.  

I definitelly have a new favorite place to eat!

Ramen Sora is the 2nd place I've eaten ramen at in Vegas and it is delicious! As soon as my crew and I pulled up, we saw the massive cluster of people waiting outside which meant it was bomb. I looked over the menu while we waited so that I wouldn't hesitate when it was my turn. 

I ordered the miso broth with spicy meat on the side and extra chashu pork and nori. It was fabulous! The meat wasn't that spicy but it had a good flavor. I also ordered steamed gyoza and a cold sake. No one had any food left in front of them and it was pretty quiet while everyone was eating. Another good sign of good food. I recommend Ramen Sora to those that love ramen.

Next time I'll try out Monta Ramen and compare.
This is by far the best ramen in all of Las Vegas! I order the Screaming for Vengeance spicy miso ramen, spicy broth with chewy noodles! Perfection in a bowl!!

I can say I enjoyed my visit to this establishment. The restaurant is tiny and gets very busy quickly. I would recommend coming when they open to avoid the long wait. 
The broth for the ramen comes in 3 different choices: shoyu, shio and miso. I had ordered the miso Screaming for Vengeance ramen bowl. It had chashu pork, menma, seaweed and bean sprouts. It's supposedly the most spiciest ramen in Las Vegas. I can say it wasn't nearly close to being spicy that burned. It had a slight kick but it wasn't, by my standard, spicy. But the broth was very tasty. It was a pork based miso broth. I slurped up the entire large bowl I had ordered. I loved the texture of the noodles. It wasn't too chewy and it certainly wasn't over-cooked. It was perfect to me. Perfectly chewy and enjoyable. The chashu pork was melt-in-your-mouth goodness. 
I recommend anyone checking this place out of you're in the area.

My favorite place of 2 others that I have tried.  My daughter loves their rice and is always looking forward to going here.  The service is good but they need to get some sprite lol.  I always go and order that and forget that they don't have that.

I tried their Screaming for Vengeance ramen and it was very very spicy!!!!  I had to order a different one.  I'll stick to their spicy ramen!

Best miso broth in town and if you like spicy food you will enjoy killer spicy, I recommend getting the killer meat on the side and add slowly as it can be overwhelming if you're not used to that high level of heat. The chashu is always tender and delicious. Noodles always on point, never over cooked. Highly recommend this place.
Not recommend for Togo,they put the wrong soup,and I can't even finish bc it was too spicy.

Best ramen in Vegas in my opinion, and I've lived in Japan for 6 1/2 years. I prefer it over the other popular spot in Chinatown, hands down.

Egg is always included, you don't have to pay extra. Chasu is cooked to perfection. I recommend the shoyu ramen. It always hits the spot.

Have been here many times. The one and only downside to this place is if you get there when it's busy lol. I love coming here for the spicy miso, it is amazing. The help are always friendly, not the fastest but the food more than makes up for that. Have also had the fried rice and gyoza which are both very very good. A good friend of mine always gets the deluxe and they are always satisfied.

We have been here 3x already,my family really enjoyed the ramen!  Excellent  miso broth n ramen,my personal fav is always the spicy miso.... U can order extra portions;extra noodles,broth or charsu,etc....Atmosphere is modern,nice and clean NOT overcrowded n stuffy like some other places...severs where nice n cheerful. Will be back again!

Decided to try this place with my boss based on yelp reviews. He also is a ramen fan. It was very good. Nice selection of ramen. I think this place is better than "the other ramen place down the street." Sora had more space to sit and plus did not have to wait 1 hour! Prices are very reasonable. I had the miso ramen and it was tasty and not salty at all. I would definitely go back if I ever crave ramen again.  The gyoza is tasty too!

Came back again for the deluxe Miso with extra nori and killer spicy meat. The charsiu wasn't as soft as it was the last time, but still hella good. Definitely my go to Ramen joint in Vegas.... yes, more so than Monta.

I would've given it 5 stars! I love the food but service sucks ! They're never around hard to find and they didn't let us sit bc the rest of our party was in the parking lot and not in the building so we had to give our table and had to keep waiting until another table cleared up and got attitude from a cashier bc I got upset.

ive never had real ramen until i tried Ramen Sora and its just amazing! i crave it weekly! the first time i had it i needed it 3 more times the same week. Love the Spicy Miso  Ramen. I tried the killer spicy and burned my face and insides but its was so good and im going to try again with just a side of the killer spicy meat. The service is always great whether we eat in or order to go. and try the creamy melon soda its yummy. the gyozas were good but its kinda hard to mess those up. and the mini charsu bowl was tasty too. weve had just about all the different toppings but have only had the miso broth and wouldnt dare try to screaming vengeance. my husband and my kids love the ramen too age 3 and 1.  love love Ramen sora!

Since I am a "total noob" when it comes to ramen, per Misty Y.'s review I ordered the Nori Ramen in Miso broth. This broth is super flavorful and salty, I mean really really salty and flavorful. If you are totally crazy about eating salty food, you'll love this. The dish comes with half an egg, chopped green onion, strips of bamboo shoots and some form of meat which I wasn't able to identify but I assume it may be pork. 

It is a very hearty soup with oily soft noodle in an oily meaty broth. Although it isn't something I'd want to eat regularly due to the high calories including the high fat and cholesterol content, I'd imagine many people would love this dish and obviously this place. It is decorated in a modern Asian style with nice lighting, a nice ambience and a spacious interior. 

For fans of ramen, this is a five star rating kind of place. For someone like me, I will pass on ramen noodles.

Items Selected:
Gyoza
Spicy Miso Ramen
Corn Butter Miso Ramen

Fancied by legions of fans around the world, and certainly seeing a renaissance in America that goes beyond the 25-cent cups commonly seen around college dorms, Ramen Noodles have never really held much interest to someone that really does not love soups with clear broth, but attempting to understand a trend that generates lines in America and Michelin Stars overseas it was with a friend that Ramen Sora was visited for 6 o'clock dinner, the small shop on Spring Mountain supposedly Las Vegas' best.

Small and dingy on the outside, the sort of place passers-by could easily blink and miss, Ramen Sora cites its Sapporo heritage with signage at the door and once inside the scene brightens substantially, several tables laid out with good spacing while pop-music chimes over the din of the crowd.

Smallish in menu, a few appetizers joining soups in one of three styles of broth, those arriving during peak hours should expect a short wait, the staff friendly and efficient with bowls emerging from the kitchen at a relatively rapid rate.

Opting for water and tea service, a few alcoholic selections also available to those choosing to imbibe, it was mere minutes after orders were placed before five pan-seared potstickers landed on the table, a ground chicken filling nicely textured and exceedingly juicy with a sesame based sauce served alongside for those desiring an extra bit of umami.

Onward to the soups, noodles of the pre-packaged variety and thus no different than anywhere else, it was at the advice of our waitress that the 'signature' miso soup was selected for both bowls instead of Shoyu or Shio and with a description of 'creamy' the pork infused broth was indeed rich, the spicy beef addition leaving a tingle on the lips while a small knob of butter added even more depth to the corn studded version that trended ever so slightly sweet.

Happy to see an egg and shoots added for texture, the noodles springy but rather redundant bite-after-bite, it perhaps should have been a sign when the table adjacent added several pieces of Chasu to their four-person order, the four bites of pork belly included in our bowls easily the most memorable part of the meal and so tender that it almost melts on the tongue.

***Potentially underrated by someone whose basis of comparison consists of less than a handful of noodle houses to date, it is simply difficult to get excited for something based on pre-packaged starch and pork broth served in a gigantic portion no matter how good, a menu with more options or at least more room for customization potentially something I could grow to understand and maybe even love.

Ramen sora is another great place for Japanese ramen and cuisine.  They offer well portioned size bowls that already come with a variety of toppings included with the option to add more to your hearts content. This place can get busy during peak hours and weekends but wait times are usually not that long. I am a big fan of their miso flavored ramen and I do recommend you try them! I would also recommend their pork chirasu bowls. In my opinion their chirasu is the best in town!!!! My only gripe with ramen sora is that they do not allow you to order extra noodles on the side like other ramen places in town. 4 stars for great food!

Another awesome Ramen place 2nd to Monta.

Different style, different flavor but awesome quick service and as usual this place had a line waiting outside just like Monta but not quite as crazy.

Broth and noodles both excellent, not sure if they make their noodles from scratch but they are delicious.

The charsu appetizer was excellent and had a smokey flavor to it. 

For sure will be back as this place was just that delicious.

I am an admitted Ramen snob. These people KNOW what ramen is supposed to taste like. The broth is Stupid amounts of good!!!! It is rich and dense and luxurious and has a depth of flavor that you won't find any where else in America.  The noodles are slightly al dente Sapporo noodles and the pork is melt in your mouth tended. Even the egg has been flavoured very subtly. The entire place feels like a typical Japanese ramen shop but with lots of room to accommodate us Americans with our need for personal space.
Good service, great food! Friendly waitress,  she even takes time to explained their menu!  Will come back :)

Horrible ramen, horrible service.
The place was crowded and the employees do not know how to run it smoothly. There were a few tables open and they didn't seat people right away, the had an obsession with looking at the sign in clipboard, but they wouldn't seat anyone. They would have two people bus the table when you only need one person to do the job. All the servers were running around and not getting a lot done. One of the server was blowing her nose by the chopsticks that were just washed, she threw the napkin in the trash, wiped her nose with her hand and then grabbed a handful of chopsticks, put them in the holder and put it on a table for guests to use! After we were seated a family of four sat next to us and the guy proceeded to blow his nose at the table, there is nothing worse than being in a crowded restaurant and people unload next to you. 
The ramen was way too salty, bad quality ingredients,  the noodles were good, but not good enough to return.  
The curry plate was very salty, lacked in flavor. The pork was over cooked and was not hot, it was bearly warm. 
Hot tea was not hot at all.
Gyoza was just ok.

This place is amazing! And yes, it is better than Ramen Monta, which we had just the day before. 
Hub hub had the vengeance--broth is the spiciest ramen we have ever had but quite good. 
I had the miso and it was perfection. The broth is creamy, rich and very robust in flavor and the noodles here are just the best!

We will be back for sure!!!!

Straight to the point menu. My favorite Ramen house in Vegas!!! Monta a close 2nd. I've only had the butter corn. I'm not a fan of the shrooms but allow them in for flavor. I get it Miso style. The staff is very kind. Excellent service. I gotta try the Matcha next time for dessert.

This is a good alternative to Monta. Their miso ramen could some more broth, as it's a little too thick for my liking. But wow... the super spicy option actually is spicy! Monta should take a hint from them.

I didn't care for the seaweed sheets because if you don't chomp it right away, it turns into a tangly salty ball in your soup. I'd also prefer an option for extra bamboo, but maybe I missed it that night.

Let me start off by saying I really do love the food here. I've been coming here since they've been open and I always order the same soup because it's so amazing. Their miso broth is probably one of the best I've tasted and their eggs are always cooked perfectly.  The only reason I'm giving it 2 stars is because of their service.

I went to Ramen Sora yesterday around 6:30 to 6:40. Pretty much during the dinner crowd. I had 5 people total in my party, but it only took them a few minutes to get us a table. So far, so good! Our waitress was an older Asian woman with glasses, and she took our drink orders, came back, and took our food orders. We all ordered ramen, but my boyfriend and I always get the Screaming For Vengeance miso broth with extra seaweed, extra egg, and no green or white onions. I'm very aware that the miso is cooked with onions and it tastes delicious, however, I cannot stand the texture of onions so I prefer to leave them out. I don't mind if there's a few left, just not a heaping pile of it. Anyways, it took about 6 to 8 minutes after we ordered to receive our food. Well, I mean, my party's food. I had yet to receive mine. So I waited.... and waited.... and waited some more. It took between 15 to 20 minutes for my food to come out, and I was not happy. By the time I got my food, the rest of my party was already done with theirs. The seaweed had been sitting in there too long, and it was a little too cold, but I don't like to complain when I'm hungry. I ate it and we received our check which came to almost $70. My tip to them was $3. I get it. It was busy, there was a lot of people. I'm very unhappy because the waitress didn't really seem to care, just gave me a quick "Sorry" and disappeared until the table was cleared. Anyways, another lady comes and grabs the check and looks inside, makes a face, and motions to our waitress. She points to me as if I wasn't even there, and our waitress rolled her eyes while they're pretty much badmouthing me.  We got up, and our waitress had the audacity to shake her head at me. That really made me upset. Not only is that very rude and disrespectful, but it's extremely unprofessional.  I did not appreciate that. I get that waitresses live off of tips. I live off of my tips as well. I am not going to reward bad service. My tips to someone are a privilege, not a right, and workers here in Las Vegas seem to not realize it's not your right to receive a tip. If you're going to badmouth a customer, as least do it out of sight. Or don't do it at all. Sadly, I won't be back to this place, which breaks my heart since I truly love your miso broth. But I'd rather spend my money at a place that doesn't talk smack and shake heads at their customers just because I left a $3 tip. Judging by your reactions, I'm pretty sure you deserved it.

Edit:

I decided to come back to this place because I can't stay away from their amazing killer spicy miso ramen. I'm glad I came back. Haven't had problems since. I just avoid the two ladies who were rude, and thankfully I rarely have to see them. Definitely try all their food. It's pretty great.
Love it love it love their ramen,chasu!! Killer spicy ramen is the best! Extra chasu is necessary xD

I'm changing my review to five stars because this place is truly delicious. I think the reason why I rated it a four star before was because the broth was not updated to our tastes. Once you know what you'd like to taste (less salty; extra flavor; or miso brother instead of etc) then you'll have some of the finest ramen in your life.

Cheap and delicious!

After days stuck on the Strip during my trip to Vegas, my friend drove me to Ramen Sora to try one of the many restaurants in Chinatown. The Deluxe Ramen with Miso was probably my favorite meal of the week! The pickled ginger on the side was a perfect compliment as well (my friend requested it, so I don't know if it automatically comes with meals or only by request).

It is the best ramen I've ever had. Granted... I have only tried ramen at four restaurants including Ramen Sora (one in Los Angeles, and two in Atlanta). However, the soup, the meat, and the noodles were perfect: the soup rich, the meat tender, and the noodles chewy.

The wait was a bit long on a Tuesday night, but it was definitely worth the wait. No complaints otherwise.
The food was ok and the service was bad, really bad... at least I got to try it... my friend was trying to ask for lime and the server was very rude like no lime, no lemon while walking away...
Great ramen. Not too much pork fat. Great noodles... Sapporo style. Delicious. Go now.

It only took me frozen toes to remember to write a review of Sora. After being out in the cold for a few hours, we were freezing and hungry. There was quite a wait only because we had a big group but we were just happy to be indoors. Normally, if there's only 2 people in your party, you get seated rather quickly.

I normally get gyoza with whatever ramen I get. There's enough meat filling and the wrapper isn't thick/ chewy with one side toasted for a nice crisp. I've tried their shoyu chashu ramen, miso ramen, nori ramen, shio ramen and the spicy miso ramen. Unfortunately, they ran low on chashu the last time we went - each person could only have 1 slice of pork belly each. Sad! But their chashu is soooo tasty so I'm not surprised. I like to add iwanori (seaweed flakes) and corn on my ramen. Mmmmm...the hot rich broth, the firm ramen noodles and hard-boiled egg + chashu on a cold day. I couldn't want more than that. You can wash it all down with beer, hot tea, iced tea or Ramune.

Our server was patient with us despite special requests and complications with splitting the bill. I can't think of a time I had a bad experience here.

Ramen houses are popping up all over the valley.  But, unfortunately not all ramen are created equal.  This little gem is worth the wait.  The restaurant is small and you definitely will have a wait since no reservations are taken.  Staff is super friendly and tables are turned over fairly quickly.  
Miso ramen with corn butter and spicy meat.  What can I say.  This is the creamiest, rich and flavorful broth.  Not too salty. Just full of rich umami yumminess.   The spicy meat adds some heat to the flavorful broth.  The ramen noodles are nice and chewy with s light texture.  
But the real winner at Sora is there Gyoza.  Light chewy dumpling dough that is second to none.  You have to try it!!!

Good place for ramen, and my girlfriend really loves it. However, their menma really bothers me more than it does at other places (I always ask for it on the side, whenever its served with my ramen and soup, it makes the whole thing taste bad) Aside from the menma, the broth and chashu our nice and I don't really find anything wrong with the noodles. Service is nice and the food comes out really fast, but we don't really eat there during busy hours. 

What we usually eat:
Chashu Ramen (Miso or Shoyu)
Killer Spicy Ramen (Miso)

My only gripes are with how they serve drinks aside from water. They give you cans and bottles instead of having a soft drink dispenser. Also, no tonkotsu broth, which is my favorite type of broth.
Great ramen! The pork belly is so tender and it just dissolves in your mouth. The prices are reasonable and the atmosphere is nice. If I lived here I would definitely return.

Love love love Ramen Sora. I come here quite frequently with friends. Ever since my family started taking me here, it's been our go to place. Service is quick and fast and the employees are always on top of it. 

I ALWAYS get the Large Deluxe sized Ramen with either miso broth or shoyu broth depending on my mood. Most of the time, I get the miso broth. I always request to take out the bamboo shoots only because it has this weird texture... but that's just my opinion. They have regular, large, and the big boy "super sized."

Parking can be a hassle on a busy night but that is expected. It is also expected that the line will be out the door on a chilly night. Give this place shot. I, myself prefer Ramen Sora over MONTA because of the broth in my preference. The broth here is way better and isn't creamy or thick.

Went here tonight n had the spicy ramen with vengeance.....WOW!!! I'm in love!!! No sh*tn about spicy that was awesome!! My 5months son in my belly is kicking up the storm, this place is one of the best ramen, been to San Fran n had good ones but this was Delish!!!!!

delish! best morning after meal esp on a chilly vegas day. the place can easily be missed unless you're looking for it. standalone on a busy street, with a small parking lot, the inside is even smaller with a few large tables. the wait staff is very nice and attentive.

ordered the miso ramen with corn. flavors were good, noodles were perfect. only note was that it came with only one piece of chashu where other places at least give you two. good thing i didnt care for meat that day as the noodles and soup base was juuust right.

We went to Vegas in mid-December where the weather was pretty cold so we decided to have ramen (Japanese noodles soup). One of my sister's friends recommended this place. From the outside the place is not in a good part of Vegas. The inside looks small and old. However, the ramen was super good. The menu is very simple. My tolerance for spicy food is considerably high so I had their spiciest ramen called "screaming for vengeance" which is spicy but not too spicy where I could not finish. The soup is very tasty but a bit too salty for me still. We came in a group of 13: my family, my sister's & my cousin's family. We all like the food so much that we all came back the next day. This is definitely a place for you to eat when you visits Vegas. The fried rice is delicious.
I tried Orochan in LA but their soup on the spicy ramen is so salty where I can't finish without drinking water to dilute the salt. I found a new ramen place in Arcadia (Yukinoya ramen) and their soup is scrumptious and not too salty. We come to this place a lot.

small area, if you are there at a busy time you will end up waiting long in the corner of the area. overall, the food was really good. i only heard praises from other people. i had the miso butter corn ramen & it was a little sweet for my taste buds, but nonetheless it was still very good. too spice it up a bit, the red pepper on the table can customize to your liking. i put 4 stars instead of 5 because of the waiting area & time.

Our friends brought us here from Atlanta. We tried the regular, spicy and Killer spicy ramens and all of them were awesome!
The starters: Gyoza and Pork curry bowl were really good too.
Wait time wasn't too long on a Friday, around 1/1:30 PM.
Loved it! Sets the stage for comparison to authentic ramen now.
Oh, definitely try the mango ice cream dessert!! Very unique and delicious.

**Summary**
       - Ramen - Their ramen is a bit thicker than your average ramen. It's suppose to be an original recipe from Saporro Japan.
       - Flavor - Their barbecued pork is unrivaled in its tastiness. Since practically everything on the menu includes it, you'll probably try it in one of their dishes.
       - Saltiness - All the dishes were a little too salty for me, but all the good ramen places in Vegas seem super salty. With that said, it's less salty than Monta, which was my previous ramen place.
       - Super size - You can order a large version of the ramen bowls for $1 more.
**Ramen**
       - I got a bit confused with the menu when I first looked at it, so here's my explanation of the ramen.
       - Two things main things make up the base. One is pork and the other you have a choice of Miso or Shio (Salt).
       - They all come with half an egg, one piece of pork, and menma (bamboo shoots).
          - Chashu Ramen has 2 extra pork pieces.
          - Menma Ramen has extra menma.
          - Spicy Ramen has a ground meat/Rayu (Chili oil) sauce scoop added in to be mixed around. It's not spicy at all. Taco bell mild sauce is spicier.
          - Corn Butter ramen had corn and a slice of butter added.
          - Nori Ramen has seaweed added to the side.
          - Negi Ramen has a piece of fish replacing the pork.
          - Deluxe Sora Ramen has 2 extra pork pieces and nori (seaweed) added.
**Ordered**
       - $10.00 Deluxe Shio Ramen (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4k3RlMAMd46DZ_JyZU0lMg?select=bs_GyeafgqHE1QlNfTP69g)
       - $8.50 Spicy Miso Ramen (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4k3RlMAMd46DZ_JyZU0lMg?select=J6COHikJJ6CviUN8mzSoiA)
              - Soup - Both soups are slow-cooked in pork bones. You can see the pork oil floating in the soup. It really adds a deliciously meaty flavor to the soup.
              - Miso - The miso soup is thicker and heartier than the shio. 
              - Shio (Salt) - I much preferred the shio soup. The consistency is less thick and the flavor a lot more clean.
              - Chashu (barbecued) - The meat literally falls apart it's very tender and the pork is literally a flavor bomb.
       - $2.85 Mini Chashu or Chashu Curry Bowl (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4k3RlMAMd46DZ_JyZU0lMg?select=OWti3brKP7toeyxM1L0XGg)
              - Mini Chashu Bowl - Their signature chashu pork on rice. Out of the soup, it really allows you to taste the full flavor of the meat, though it's a smidge saltier than in the soups. Even though meat the rice ratio was a little lacking, it makes for a delicious snack.
              - Mini Chashu Curry Bowl - The chashu pork in curry over rice. The serving of meat is less due to the curry. The curry is so-so and a bit salty. Added with everything else, I think it's a bit too much. I'd prefer the regular Chashu Bowl.
**Recommendations**
       - I'd recommend this place for a nice authentic ramen restaurant.

I genuinely like Ramen Sora for how rich their broth is. It has a robust flavor that is unlike any other place in Vegas. It can be overpowering, but I found that it was just complex and hearty.

I had started with the small bowl of charshu curry. I will be the first to admit that I have had my fair share of bad curry, especially of the Japanese variety, and have develop a phobia about trying it again. I got so many shocked reactions due to my declaration against it that I had to try it again. It was actually very good. I like their pickled radish here. It is slightly sweet and paired well with the curry. A few days later, I made a curry for a potluck and I might not dislike the Japanese version as much as I initially thought. I was still ravenous and ordered a bowl of the menma ramen as well. I am a huge fan of bamboo. It can be fresh, cured, or dried. If it is an option, I am ordering it. Especially if it is the main component of the dish. I ended up stealing all of my friends, too. Sora offers a solid bowl of soup.

The broth is watery and barely has flavor. I am from LA and I have been to a few ramen places in little tokyo and in westwood and this place cannot even be mentioned in the same sentence as them. I am not sure if vegas lacks good ramen places but to rate this place so highly is confusing and disappointing. Santouka ramen, jinya ramen, daikokuya, tsujita and many other ramen restaurants make sora ramen unnecessary and a con operation for people who have never tried really good ramen. Worst than the food, however, was the attitude of the server who I later found out was the manager. I accidently wrote our name on the second page of the waitlist because i did not see the two columns of spaces to write down names on the first page. That was my mistake but still i notified them of my mistake and that it was my turn to be sitted. The manager, her name is Shinaya or something like that, hestitantly took me to be sitted at the bar but I wanted to sit at a table. Then the manager rolled her eyes and gave me attitude for wanting to sit there. Upon talking with the manager because my appetite had been ruined by the managers rude behavior she tried to justify her actions by telling me she let me sit there instead of another couple of customers who came after me.
