The manager said this couple are regulars and that they didnt want to sit at the bar either. Even when I told her that i came before her she still insisted that she did me a service by giving me the table instead of them. BTW there were other tables available it was not too busy at the time. The manager did not apologize until I reminded her she didn't even apologize for ruining my experience there; she just kept trying to justify her rude behaviour. She refused to give me the name of her superior and would not give me the name of anyone else who I could speak with regarding her terrible attitude to a customer. So for whoever decides to go here for a less than mediocre bowl of ramen just know the manager, SHINAYA, is unprofessional and dont expect too much from this place.

Don't be turned off by the fact that this place doesn't serve tonkotsu ramen.  In the U.S., we tend towards the stronger, more flavorful broths, which is a reason why tonkotsu became so popular.  If you try their Miso ramen, you'll experience a rich pork based, miso infused broth that's just absolutely delicious!  I passed on Ramen Sora so many times during past trips to Vegas because well, how good can a ramen place be when it's located next to Chinatown?  How wrong I was, and as a ramen lover (as a baseline, Ichiran in Japan is my all time fav), this place is legit!  TIP:  The waitress recommended having the killer spicy meat on the side, and it was a great suggestion!  This way the ground beef doesn't get lost in the broth, so you can enjoy every single last morsel with your noodles.
A great meal...inexpensive and will fill you up. Flavorful and really unique!! Just be prepared for a long wait...it's a small restaurant that is extremely popular!!

Monta Ramen can kiss Ramen Sora's delicious booty!

I was thrilled to find out that Vegas' China Town has PLENTY of other great ramen spots besides the super popular (and yucky) Monta Ramen. 

When I was here I ordered myself a bowl of the Corn & Butter Ramen with a side order of spice (which basically means a heaping scoop of spicy meat, yes, meat!). 

I'm glad I decided to come here for a random late lunch because I can tell this place also gets packed. Especially since their food is ON POINT.

-Ramen noodles are THICK baby and cooked perfectly. 
-Broth is BOMB. Not too salty and temperature is HOT, not lukewarm like what we experienced over at Monta Ramen.
-Soft boiled egg also delicious.
-Any bowl of ramen with corn automatically gets bonus points from me. 

I seriously still dream about the ramen I had here. Thank goodness I vlog ever so often and was able to capture this deliciousness the weekend I was there: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qTRkO0AT9sE

One of our favorite go to spots. We love the ramen. I prefer the corn and butter ramen and the hubs spicy miso ramen. The kids love the pork fried rice and this place even caters the ramen to kids! My daughter loves soups so it works great for her, she gets the miso soup with noodles only.

First things first: I feel like I must weigh in on the age old (okay 6 month old) debate of Monta or Sora?   I.... I....  I'm giving it a tie.   Boooooooooooo!

Yeah, I can't call it.  Decided to finally visit Sora this past Friday and had been extremely intrigued by all the yelpers who prefer Sora over Monta and vice versa.  I actually convinced myself that Sora probably had better Ramen because even though I love Monta's version, I've sort of gotten bored of it and find myself ordering the Pork Belly Bowl more often.   

Decided to go with the Spicy Miso bowl and was also fortunate enough to be able to try the Shoyu Ramen as well.  I really liked the noodles at Sora, moreso than Monta as I felt they were more al dente than what I've had at Monta which is what I prefer.  The pork and egg gave me the same pleasurable dining experience that I get from Monta.   As for the broth, in the beginning I actually thought it was a little bland, even after I tried to mix it all up.   With each bite, it became better and better and by the end of my bowl, I felt it had a lot of depth.   The next time I go I actually think I'm going to hold off a few minutes before digging right in as difficult as that will be to do.   The longer those ingredients, and in particular the spicy ground pork, stew in the broth, the better.  I think overall I found it to be as enjoyable as my favorite broth at Monta, the tonkatsu.

I also tried some of the Shoyu broth and actually wasn't impressed with it.   I thought it tasted fairly thin and not nearly as flavorful as Monta's version. I do need to explore their side offerings some more before trying to break this tie, but for now it is what it is.   To the owners of Monta and Sora: I accept bribes (to the Yelp Elite Council:  just kidding)

My first visit to Ramen Sura this past week was a good experiance, the server was very helpful explaining the different types of Ramen.  I end up choosing the delux with both pork belly and sea weed sheets. It was great. The restaurant is clean, service is good and price is fair. They have parking and open late.
Best ramen in Vegas! Definitely will come back here when I visit again. Quick service and probably the tastiest miso broth I've had...ever.

Wow, this place looks like nothing on the outside but has excellent food. The pork was spectacular. The killer hot meat was really really hot.  The gyozq was super legit. We also had a seared meat appetizer that blew us away.  Can't remember the name unfortunately. Anyway,  service was A+ as well as the food. The price was low too. Much recommended.

Take this with a grain a salt because I am very picky about my ramen. I ordered the Spicy Shio Ramen. The noodles were a good consistency, nice texture and everything. The only thing I felt had an issue was the Shio broth, yes I know Shio means salt and that is a very bland broth but it wasn't very flavorful to me. There wasn't much depth to it even with the spicy sauce it had. The hubby liked the Shoyu Ramen though so I can't say it was all bad. Just wish the Shio broth had more oomph to it.

My husband and I wanted to try a new ramen place and he'd read reviews about this one.  When we stopped in, the place was crowded but we managed to get a seat. 

After a good look at the menu, our orders were placed.  I got the shio ramen, it was small but flavorable with a couple of big pieces of chashu pork.  The half boiled egg was still slightly runny, and the noodle was what I call true ramen noodle, at least what I had been used to getting in Hawaiian Ramen shops.

Overall, a good bowl of soup, but it didn't fill me up, so either order extra sides, or make it large, or you're gonna leave hungry.

Service was good unfortunately too much pork fat in the Miso Ramen and My husband didn't ask for hair in his food. Guess the hair was free. I can deal with bad service just don't like objects in our food.

I ordered the spicy ramen bowl in miso broth and it was so delicious!  The flavor of the sliced pork and spicy ground pork reminded me of my mother's flavors and that is hard to do. Needless to say I downed this bowl quickly.  I may have even took a breathe in between bites but I am not sure. Service was fantastic and quick. I highly recommend this place for noodle enthusiasts.

This place is amazing if you love ramen. I travel here almost every day with a friend, and the service is always terrific and kind. You get everything pretty quickly. The fried rice is delicious. No complaints the stuff is on the ball.

Ordered: chasu ramen $9, mini chasu curry $2.85, and gyoza $3.75 - food and service was a 4/5.  Prices were decent...restaurant was a bit hot and seating is very drab (and hard).  Parking is along the back of restaurant...all
in all, I could see myself coming back to Ramen Sora (Waaaayyy better than Anime Ramen).

Get ready for some vengeance! 

I like going outside of the Vegas strip and tourist attractions to see what amazing food adventures we can stumble upon. Well, with the help of Yelp, I searched for ramen and bam! This was on the top of the list! It must be really good, oh wait, it goes by distance...oh well. Anyway, from the reviews I read, it is a really great place that many locals seem to go to. Great, I thought, that means we can get great quality ramen minus the high Vegas pricing! This place is in the heart of Chinatown. The reviews are right! Thank you locals for helping me add this into my food adventure! Plus, anything within range of a university means 1.) cheap food and 2.) amazingly delicious food! Score!

The place is small and can probably fit about 30 people. The wait can be long, but we got there relatively early and were seated within 10 minutes. It is a very cozy setting and the staff is very friendly. They gave great recommendations. The menu was easy to follow and had really good pictures and descriptions of the food items. I like 2 sided menus because that means that there popular items are all that matters and everything flows well and that the restaurant focuses on it's specialties. I got the spicy miso ramen which was filling and provided great warmth considering it was freezing outside! My cousin got the Super Vengeance, which is supposed to be a very spicy miso ramen. She tells me it's not that spicy, but she has a pretty high tolerance for spicy food! I loved the green tea that they served because it was hot and crisp and felt very clean. The soups were very delicious and not as salty as some other ramen places I know. Glad we found this place to fill our bellies but to also keep us warm. 

It was great meeting the locals as well for they gave more recommendations as to where to find good eats (bookmarked!). I felt like Andrew Zimmerman on the travel channel...SO dreams do come true?!?

Great ramen ! Great price! Broths are flavorful and not too fatty. I feel the same about the pork. Sometimes there is too much fat on the pork slices they put on top, but not at this place. The place isn't too small and you aren't sitting on top of other customers which is the problem I have with Monta Ramen. This is for sure one of my fave ramen joints.

I enjoy ramen but it usually isn't the first choice for noodles for our family. But this time, we had a guest with us who made the final call for Sora. I'll always lean toward something with a little more heat and Sora has the spiciest ramen I've ever had called the Screaming for Vengeance.

We had a 15 minute wait for the very small dining room on a mid Saturday afternoon, but there's seating inside and a bench outside for you to relax once you put your name on the list. Service was friendly and fast for us as we were in and out in about 45 minutes. It's a pretty small menu with no tonkotsu. You can choose to have a bowl that's focused on a specific topping such as nori, negi, or menma. The "deluxe" is the way to go if you like all the toppings.

As for my miso Screaming for Vengeance, don't let the heavier broth with a nice lump of killer spicy meat fool you into thinking this is some kind of docile animal. It's a beast and the heat hit me midway, at the end, and stayed way past its welcome all the way until a couple of hours later when I could still feel some burning in my stomach. I'd give it an easy 8/10, pushing 9 to the point where I needed every napkin to dry off the lingering effects of the heat. I still enjoyed the noodles and the chasu, but the heat was right on the border of too much.

Also ordered were a miso ramen and two shoyu chashu ramens. All bowls were slurped up quickly and without complaint. The total was $43 for four. Next time, I'll ask if they charge for buckets of water so I can have one readily available to dump over my head.

Just a day off with the bestie and we decided on ramen.  When I think of ramen I have to admit I think of instant ramen I make at home with my own toppings and such.  First off, it looks like a big heaping bowl, like you can't finish it.  But you can, and you will, and it's amazing.  They are still in the beginning of their journey, this restaurant, so it wasn't a full bar or anything but it was so good I didn't need a beer or wine.

I ate here last Sunday afternoon for lunch with friends.  There was only one waitress who was nice, but she seemed overwhelmed.  This was understandable because there were a lot of people waiting when we were finally seated and even more were walking in.  We each ordered the spicy miso ramen and we all got sick.  Worst part of my Vegas experience.

Nah! Not all that great, didn't hit the spot for us :(

Started of with some Gyozas - they were perfect!

 My husband and I ordered the spicy miso ramen - the ramen here doesn't taste all that great. The noodles are thick, broth was overly overly salty, oily and seems like they put what ever spicy flavor in there to make it spicy like red pepper flakes. Which I thought was funny, cuz I've never seen that before.  And there eggs isn't soft boiled :( and they don't give you enough broth. 

Chashu fried rice - it had a different flavor, didn't do it for us. Had to pack it to go and had it for dinner, cuz I didn't want to waste money :( 

My little man had the mini pork chashu bowl - meh :/ to much fat and burnt meat. Flavor wasn't there. My baby didn't like it so we asked the manager to take it back. The owner was rude and seems to have an attitude.

I had the deluxe ramen  and my girlfriend had the miso ramen with extra corn. We also ordered a chashu  bowl but we devoured it before we had a chance to take a picture!  The ramen is just the total package broth was delicious ,pork was thick and tender, and the noodles were thick and delicious. What more do you want.

Enjoyed a bowl of the spicy ramen. Very flavorful. The meat and egg were seasoned well and cooked to perfection. The noodles were a medium-thick. Also enjoyed the garlic edamame which had a creamy/buttery flavor, yum. Can't wait to go back.

I ordered the deluxe ramen with shoyu broth and the cha shu rice. My favorite part about the ramen were the noodles. They didn't feel like the regular ramen noodles I was used to, but instead was a little firm and thick which I very much liked. It made it easy to slurp. The rice bowl wasn't too exciting and maybe I'll try the curry bowl next time, but all in all the good and service was great.

Ehhh I feel this place is overrated; I've had better at many ramen shops in both LA and in LV. They don't have tonkotsu and their egg isn't soft-boiled which is somewhat disappointing. 

They also charged a dollar extra for the shio soup base which is something I did not expect and I also did not see such charge on the menu.

Best ramen EVER!!
We often go to Vegas, not to gamble but for the amazing variety of food you can get. Chinatown always has something new to offer, no matter how many times you have been there. We went to Ramen Sora for an early lunch after reading great reviews and we were not disappointed. The place is quite popular, so be prepared to wait. The crowd keeps moving pretty quickly so the wait is not too long. We had to wait for like 7-10mins but that actually helped us to read through their personal ads for what they recommend you to have while you are there. We ordered all there recommended items - Chasu Bowl, The Miso Ramen with Spicy Meat and the Pan Fried Dumplings. The dumplings were very fresh. Loved the ramen - it was perfectly spicy and the broth was fabulous enough to cure a sick man. The Chasu bowl was also very nice - loved the favors and texture of the dish overall. Definitely going back to this place on my next trip again!

Back again for the annual xmas/new year vacation in LV.  Got a clueless waiter this time.  Ordered the deluxe and asked for xtra onion, egg, and pork(which are all xtra $) but dude said he couldn't add the pork; WTF? I asked how come and he said they were running low and saving for soup orders; no big deal.  15 mins later while eating my soup, the table next to me got 4 orders of pork/curry rice bowls; thought they were running low?  Also, I had to keep calling waiter to refill water and for utensils...as always, soup on point but service on this visit was terrible.

I went here a few weeks ago and got the screaming in vengeance ramen with extra charshu and egg. It was so gooood, literally made my nose run. Also tried the porkbelly over rice, curry and pork fried rice, all very tasty.  Also, the food came out super fast but we were there mid-day.

Spicy romen miso! The best romen I've had ever in life. 
I never finish my food but here I did. There  is always a wait but it's worth it. You usually can get a seat 20-30 minutes from when you arive. Food comes out quick.

Driving through Vegas, found this off of Yelp reviews. Boy was I glad we stopped. 

I don't know who's idea it was to put butter and corn in ramen, but I am sold. This ramen was some of the best I have ever had: noodles with just the right amount of chew, The shoyu (soy sauce broth) was flavorful and not too salty. Everything was great.

Now let me tell you what BLEW MY MIND.. 

Whatever you do, don't pass up the appetizer menu. The Seared Pork Chashu ($4) was one of the best things I have ever eaten. Period. Seared and smoky on the outside, tender tender tender on the inside. A little ribbon of fat that just melts in your mouth. Sauce that compliments the meat perfectly with out overpowering it. This is the kind of dish that converts vegetarians. This is the kind of dish that pigs dream about becoming. 

Forget the strip, forget an overpriced buffet, just don't forget to get here early.. the place fills up fast.
I had both sora and Monta as well and I liked sora better.  However,  Monta is good too.  I don't mind either place but if I had to choose I would choose sora.

I'm officially a traitor....Ramen Sora has won my heart and I have forsaken Monta.  I went back to Monta once since eating at Sora...and the soup just seemed lack luster.  The broth didn't seem as rich and thick as Sora's....although the pork is still good there...the pieces of pork at Sora are bigger.  Bigger is always better =P.  Each time at Sora has been consistently good, versus at Monta sometimes the broth is too salty, sometimes it is too watery.  I've also noticed at Monta, there has been a shift in the kitchen staff....not all of them are Japanese anymore....

I ate at Ramen Sora but finally had time to sit down and review. I experienced my first ramen place in Vegas at monta. Now I wanted to try Ramen Sora.

Place is small but still didn't feel overly crowded at least when I went with my friends. It has a small parking lot so I can imagine parking being bad when it's packed. The service was friendly and on point. Now for the food. You must know that Monta Ramen and Ramen Sora do different styles. I would have to rate them both great!!

I had the Deluxe "Sora" Ramen and everything was tender and the broth was wonderful. If you order a large remember it is a large and I hope you brought your appetite haha. My girlfriend had some type of curry and liked it. I definitely will be going back!

I've tried Monta and Fukumimi before and Ramen Sora is still better than those 2. Not that they're bad or anything, but Ramen Sora has better flavors in my opinion. Monta's soup is too salty and thick. Fukumimi is too plain.

Some nights, Ramen Sora can get so busy and depending on the size of your group, sometimes you end up waiting for almost an hour. The plus side is that once you order, you get your food in less than 10 minutes. 

Ordering the regular size keeps you satisfied. Get the large or super size if you're REALLY hungry. 

Service is okay. They're not rude, but not super friendly/helpful.

Quality ramen selection - three different broths and the noodles were perfect texture.  The miso was very flavorful but got a bit dense with the noodle starch and pork belly.  Next time I'll try the shio broth instead, which is thinner. Nothing spicy so you'd be safe upgrading to the hotter soup and/or meats.  Wish the appetizer menu was bigger - spring rolls maybe?

This place specialized is sapporo ramen (buttered corn).   

I had low expectations since I'm in SoCal and we have some of the best ramen in the country (Torrance).   I found this place to be surprisingly good.  Not as good as SoCal but I've had a lot of places that were much worse.   

If you don't know what to order, just get the combo.  You'll get some fat slices of pork, bamboo shoots and seaweed.

Park is really small. Located in Chinatown.   Wait can be long.

YUK!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I was so excited to finally eat here after reading all of the reviews. I was shocked that everything was cooked in pork. The only thing not cooked with pork was the fried rice. No beef or chicken, just pork. The broth is soaked in pork bones for one day. They have no vegetable or beef broth and you can see the grease in the broth, look at all of the posted pictures. The food smelled foul. I had a hard time getting anyone to really eat the noodles because of the smell, so we ordered more rice and began to fight over it. We brought most of the noodles home and threw them away the following day. My son eats almost anything and he would not touch the leftovers. If you are not a pork enthusiast, stay far away from this place. The service was mediocre. We sat at the table next to the bar and had a hard time getting water refills.The prices are more than reasonable. They only have about 10 tables or less in this place. And, it is very dark.
First time here and really enjoyed it. My new lunch spot when in the area... Outstanding service and excellent ramen

This was my go to spot for ramen visited this place many times over the years. One thing I have noticed is it seems to me they have changed the recipe, the meat I remember used to be thin sliced and fatty and Lott's of noodle in regular size bowl. Now they have thick meat that is kind of dry to me I wish they would bring back how I remember it. The dinning room is small and this place is always busy they should make the cashier area into a ramen bar in my opinion so people can sit around the ramen bar and eat when it gets super busy. The last visit I took my two brothers one orders a large and the other a regular I got a regular size bowl too. Seems like if your wanting more noodles large is the way to go. I finished my bowl before them and they couldn't finish there's so I poured both of there's in mine and eat all of it because I am Naruto and I love ramen and the broth here is still really good. I doubt my review will change there recipe back and the next time I go I see that fatty thin slice meat I remember and love, chances are I will be returning and who knows maybe I will be surprised and will have my favorite ramen shop in Vegas back if this happens I will be updating my review for sure. Good day and if you eat here hope you enjoy.
Service here past !!! Staff are friendly . I order the Miso ramen , it is super delicious. I love it . Will be back !

A friend mentioned she came here on a whim and recommended I try it. 

So I yelped it and stupid me...this is the ramen place I think about when eating Ramen! I mean, how could I forget about a ramen spot that I would eat at while pregnant with my 3rd child! Welp, 4th child came soon after and apparently I gave birth to my brain cells as well.

We usually would have to wait since it doesn't hold much seating, and it is typically busy...on nights we've gone. I really enjoy my shoyu ramen from there. My noodles aren't ever over-cooked and the broth is pretty on point. I usually give up my meat to the hubby. I'm just one of those folks who enjoys their ramen real simple. 

Husband usually gets the deluxe or miso ramen and he lerrrvvves it! The broths are so hearty. 

I believe there is a Ramen Sora in Japan that are from the same owners. Perhaps the authenticity of it makes their ramen so enjoyable.

 Cold nights and you're craving Ramen...certainly give this place the green light 

I'd recommend leaving the strollers IN the car though.

I like Ramen Sora. I like how it's in it's own separate vicinity, which means they have their own parking lot, which also means no angry Asian lady ripping her hair apart trying to get a damn parking spot. I also like their miso broth, jam-packed with umami, and from what I know, most akin to my taste-buds. 

Usually, my visits end with a good feeling in my mind, heart, and tummy, but I couldn't quite stomach that same feeling during my last two experiences. 

Perhaps it was because I decided to try new bowls apart from my usual corn and butter bowl, but I ordered the deluxe bowl from one visit and the chashu bowl on another visit. 

On my first visit, the service was just lacking greatly. Water wasn't served until 15 minutes into our seating and I doubt the waitress heard my order correctly because when I asked her why there wasn't butter on my ramen, she had a look as if she didn't know there was even supposed to be butter in the first place. 

On my second visit, when I ordered the chashu ramen bowl, everything tasted great except for the star of the bowl itself! Usually Ramen Sora's chashu is almost creamy, if I say so myself. Like other reviewers quote, a "perfect ration between meat and fat." It's almost like it melts in your mouth. Two out of the three pieces in my bowl were just the opposite of tender, and left me giving them to my partner since he'll eat anything. Ruined my appetite.

Despite these two recent experiences, I still have to admit that Ramen Sora is good at what it's supposed to do, and that's to make a good bowl of ramen at a decent price and experience. I won't let these two blunders affect my rating as I know how good this shop can be when it really tries to, despite their obvious inconsistencies. 

Next time, I'll just opt out of so much chashu, and stick to the same old one amazing piece that you get in every bowl.

This is my favorite ramen place in the city. They have the best-tasting ramen broth and noodles in my opinion. I usually come here on lunch break. Whether you're coming with a small or large group, I recommend arriving a little before they open for lunch and you're guaranteed to be seated quickly. Sometimes even if you arrive right when they open or only a little after, there could be a wait already. My favorites to get are the deluxe, corn butter, and spicy, all with miso broth. The portions are perfect, although the deluxe is a bit more filling (obviously). The broth is so flavorful and thick, super delicious. I've come here at night a few times, and there has always been a wait. If you're really craving for some good ramen, it's worth the wait. The service is good, pretty quick considering how busy they get. Definitely one of my to-go places for ramen, and one of my favorites in town!

If you haven't noticed, I'm as white as they come. So last night was my very very first experience with ramen **gasp!** - well, aside from the $0.10 packages you buy at the grocery store. To be quite honest I didn't know what to expect. I should have known I was in good hands with a group of Yelpers.. many of them of Asian decent. (Is that PC? Christina W. where are you when I need you??)

The wait was long, but I take that as a sign of quality, not weakness. We did have a party of 12 so what does one expect? I was just grateful that my fingers and toes were able to thaw from our Yelp Helps event.

The menu was complicated for someone who didn't know the first thing about ramen, in that there aren't really descriptions for anything. But I was pleased to see that every ramen offering had a photo. So really my decision was a matter of what looked the tastiest or least complicated. I settled on Miso Ramen $7.50. I figured it was a good basic and if it was yummy I could try something more adventurous next time.

The noodles are handmade on location and were thick and tasty - not at all like the store bought packages I grew up with. The meat was tender and fell apart at the slightest touch. I wasn't starving, so I took most of it home to the bf who gobbled up the leftovers (his first time with ramen too). I was pleasantly surprised at how good it really was.

The service once seated was top notch. Our waitress was patient, split our checks and got everyone's order correct with the exception of one missed green tea. Not an easy task when dealing with 12 yelpers who were taking pictures and taking notes.

Hooray for ramen I say! A great way to warm up on a cold winter night!

I want tons of ingredients in my ramen.  I'm the one with multiple ticket toppings when using the ramen coin order machines in Japan.  Extra, extra, extra!!  The deluxe ramen was my only choice.  I already plan on getting even more of their fantastic chashu next time.

I'm not big on miso ramen.  Not that I dislike it but it's never my first choice.  The shio was great and I thoroughly enjoyed every slurp of the noodles.  My wife opted for the miso butter corn ramen, a northern Japan specialty, which she liked a lot. 

Based on the Yelp buzz, it was a flat out guarantee to see a Yelper in the house.  Nice seeing My and Thao T with their little, future food connoisseur in tow!

Solid ramen place but I felt like my meal was incomplete without a big bottle of Asahi Super Dry (no liquor license yet?) and good gyoza.  The gyoza was below average.  I definitely like this place over Monta.  My wife refuses to step into Anime due to the manga otaku factor so I can't compare that yet.  My deluxe ramen might come out to $16 on future trips.
Good food. Big portions. Of course that's because we got the super size. Means there is left overs for lunch. Broth was good and hearty. We'll come back.

I was on my way from Southern California to Zion National Park last weekend. I wanted to try a ramen place so I did my homework on yelp before the trip. Ramen Sora got good reviews so I gave it a try when I made a stop at Vegas. I ordered the Sora Deluxe Ramen. $10 for this portion is not generous but not too bad. The taste is ok. They forgot to put any bamboo roots in my bowl. I talked to the waiter and he said they are really sorry. I think for vegas standard, the ramen might be good. For southern California standard, this is kind of average.

All the other reviews nailed parking etc so I'll agree it's a lil bit sketch, as me and my boyfriend were pulling in and straight saw someone back into another car in the lot and just drive away as if she wasn't responsible. Fortunately and unbeknownst to her as she didn't care to check, the bumper only got a slight scratch. But still. 
Anyway...check yo car on the way out. Service was friendly and fast as we were meeting people already there and who go there regularly. I asked for no meat in my Ramen but did get gyoza which was good and reminded me of my best friends' who is half Japanese. My man loved his..I can't even tell you what we got, something w seaweed obvi, but pix(sorry). Four stars because when we first got in the music was loud but talkable, barely. Then it got so loud as we ate I wanted to look around for the DJ and flashing lights because dang! I could barely hear my man next to me. And I asked for hot tea but received pre-kettled and poured hot water lightly scented w tea. And while every one else really loved this food...I did not like this. Neither  the noodles(texture) nor broth(salt seemed the main flavor), or the fact that the bamboo shoots were so over cooked they were barely recognizable as bamboo shoots (a grayish brown string)and were cut long and thin like fries. Good thing I didn't order extra bamboo shoots. The egg also ends up gray for the white part..even though the broth isn't gray? ?
Again...I didn't like it but enough people do so that my review won't hurt them. I just don't get how people think overcooked bamboo shoots are good?

So I finally added another notch to my ramen belt here at sora. I came here one evening with my friend and we were happy to be seated right away. The staff were all friendly and helpful. We tried the corn butter ramen with the shoyu broth and an order of gyoza. The ramen was pretty good however it wasn't the best I've ever had, but to be fair it may have just been the type we ordered. I usually go for the miso ramen and I've never added corn or butter before. So I would definitely be willing to return and try something else.

5 IN PARADISE / 8 IN STATES

Ok so first off, don't hate... I am giving it only 3 stars because facts are facts and I've had better. I just came from Japan, where I lived for the last 7 yrs. 
with that being said.... There is a trick to this 3 rating... 
Ok so my Japanese wife is with me, and matter of fact she has only been away from our home in Japan for about a week, and already missing the food... So she yelped and found this spot. As far as authentic, she blessed off and said yes it's really Japanese ramen... However, it's not like the best. 
Her exact words were, "this is good, for America.. You know if this place was in Japan, it would get some business..."
So on a 10 pt scale... Including Japan, this ramen is about a 5..... Like Tenkaippin... HOWEVER... (Here's the catch)... As far as USA ramen places go... It's like an 8!! 
So I figured... 3 stars would do. Even Sakino JUST said to me, ehhh I don't mind coming back... Pretty good stuff. 
So don't really worry about my picky opinion. I'm a die hard true blue 110% loyal to my #1 favorite ramen spot in Okinawa and honestly nothing will ever compete... But Sakino is Japanese, from Japan, and vouched for this place. Again, she gave it a Japanese 5 but a USA 8.... And since we're obviously on the US right now.... This is the place to be. 
We both got the spicy ramen, rice, mochi ice cream. The SUPER spicy one was like crazy hot...lol. The regular spicy is just fine... No need for more. 
The rice was decent. Mochi was fine. Service friendly and nice and quick. No issues with the staff or facility! And again, I can't go above 3 stars cuz honestly TASTE wise, it's a 3 star place... But that's cuz I've been to the ramen Mecca and back... So for here, you more than likely will NOT find better ramen than this place! Take it or leave it.... 
???????

This is my first comment in Yelp, and I have to leave a five stars for this restaurant to appreciate their manager Nao and all kind staffs. I had conference in Vegas this week, so before go back to LA, we choose Sora as our last place! I tried butter miso with corn~ supper good and pork is very generous. My husband tried salt deluxe because of the size.   When my husband tried the first time salt base, he likes it a lot~  One tip for u is don't cross eat salt with miso soup as it will make miso standing out too much~ thank u Sora~ u make my day!

The food was great. The air conditioner was a small portable unit plugged in the wall during the summer and we were eating soup so that part sucked. Not sure if that's their actual A/C or if their A/C was broken. Food was really good though. I'd definitely return in the Winter.

Spicy Miso Ramen so GOOD!!!!!!
Staff care well location parking good.
But Lunch time was long line.

Don't hate me for voicing my opinion lol.. two stars in my book is rating only the flavor. When you compare it to Santouka (Costa Mesa, CA) or Asa (Gardena, CA) .. yeah this place is aite but I have experienced better :s 

In terms of flavor, the rating that this place has really lived up the hype for me. I came here with high hopes hoping this would be thick, flavorfulass soup that Asa or Santouka would bring but alas. It was more on the thin side and the spicy miso that I chose was made differently. It did not come as a paste as it normally does, this was infused with pork, so my pescatarian friend was unable to eat it :s

The noodles were very chewy and the egg was okay.. I liked that it was runny but it wasn't mindblowingly good like other places that do not come to mind. 

The pork was super thick. It was on the tender side and was marbled with bits of the luscious fat but it didn't make my eyes roll back.. 

Service was aite. There was a wait on a Saturday afternoon at 2pm, prolly like 20 minutes.. 

In terms of quantity, it was very, very filling. I had to togo it so that I wouldn't get kbbq full.

My wife and I decided to mingle with the locals after spending way too much money on the Vegas Strip.  Found this place on YELP after having a craving for Japanese Ramen.  The last place I had been for true Japanese Ramen was Ippudo in NY so this had a lot to live up to!  

They have a few other things on the menu but come here for the Ramen.  It is a noodle soup dish with added ingredients of pork, seaweed, corn, eggs or greens.  Really your choice.  I opted for the Deluxe with everything in it and was not disappointed.  The key to any ramen restaurant is the soup.  I have read some of the other reviews that felt the broth was hit or miss but on the night we were there it was spot on!  You want to save the broth it is so good and you will find yourself licking the bowl after you drink from it!  

Compared the restaurants on the strip this place is dirt cheap!  Great food at a great price... very refreshing in Vegas.  This restaurant is located in the China Town.  Really not that far the north end of the strip.  It is located on Spring Mountain Road which is just West of the strip from the Fashion Mall.  

Take a cab, or rent a car.  Heck walk it!  Just try it you'll like it!

Words can not describe the outstanding food served at Ramen Sora.  The broth is amazingly delicious.  The internal garnish with each dish compliments every flavor you can expect in the broth.   It's truly a special place that I just love.  I always get an extra Tamago with my bowl.  :)  Do yourself a favor and go eat a bowl of Ramen at Ramen Sora.

We always go to our usual pho spot for the hangover cure, but our friend who is a local suggested ramen. It was a pretty hot day and ramen still sounded like a good cure. So off we went and we passed by the famous pho spot. I asked my friend what she orders and she said the chasiu pork over rice.. ok, now I'm hesitant of my so called friend's taste buds. How are you going to a Ramen spot to order a rice bowl? I mean, come on.. right? 

So we order and the chasiu pork over rice comes out as the appetizer. I didn't even take a picture of it since it didn't look that great. It was kinda charred. Once we started eating and OMFG.. I take all my words and bad thoughts I had about my so called friend. At that moment, I initiated her into my foodie group. This rice bowl was freaking AHmazing! So amazing that I'm back here again the day after to eat only this dish before I head to the airport.

The Ramen is pretty damn good here too!! Best meal of my short trip here. Thanks, Kit!!

This place is amazing. I'm actually still sitting in ramen Sora as I write this and I was so impressed I needed to start this review. Got the super spicy ramen with miso base and it was phenomenal. I had them add the spicy meat (which is ground pork mixed with chilis) on the side and ended up dumping the whole thing in. The chashu was PERFECT. I recommend some additional chashu on the side.
Also ordered some pork fried rice and Gyoza for appetizers which were also top notch. This is probably my go to ramen spot in Vegas from now on.

OVER RATING !! Saw 4 stars and gave it a try, soup base Super Salty , Meat even cold on noodle , Fried Rice Wet ??? They hired all Hispanic and cooking Japanese foods. They don't even know what they doing. At last the whole restaurant are all Indonesian people ???? A Japanese Restaurant have no one able to speak Japanese with me ???

The reason why i'm giving this a 3 stars is because the ramen here is amazing. 
However, it gave me and all my friends diarrhea. Yucky, i know. 
We ate this in the morning before heading back from Vegas to Irvine. However, our stomachs were hurting so much during the trip back. And 3 of us had to go to the restroom pretty frequently throughout the way back. 

Even though the ramen was really good, i would not pay the price of diarrhea for it again. I rather eat Subway .
This place is honestly one of the best ramen places I have ever been too. Definitely the best in Vegas. I make sure I come here every time I am in Vegas.

Food for thought, some say ramen is a derivative of the Chinese dish, laomien...remember most oriental ethnicities are distant descendants of China and the Japanese pronounces L's as R's...interesting huh?

Moving on, I dropped in this place when they first opened and later left since it was cash only at the time.

So I managed to return with the main squeeze since she recommended trying the place out, why not?

Do keep in mind that there is a small parking lot at the rear that can be tricky with people coming and going, so be careful when exiting to the street.

There was a 5 minute wait, which I told myself must be a good sign.  Once seated, we were sharing a large table with another group separated with a makeshift partition that was also a special menu.  Kinda like a science project board or something of the sort.

Anyhow, I read on Yelp that a lot of people enjoyed the Killer Spicy Ramen A.K.A. Screaming for Vengeance...so I had to give it a try, in shoyu broth.  Apparently they offer shio (salt), miso (fermented bean), and shoyu (soy sauce) broth...I wish they had kotteri.  In addition to that, my girl got the Deluxe Miso Ramen while I added a Curry Chashu Bowl, Gyoza and tall Kirin Ichiban draft beer.  What's puzzling to me is that if this type of ramen originated from Hokkaido, why isn't there Sapporo on tap?

It didn't take long for the food to come out and began nibbling on the Curry Chashu Bowl immediately.  Its yummy but was quick to notice that their chashu is doesn't melt in your mouth like it does at Monta.  It is, in fact, very similar to Fukimimi Ramen chashu, a little bit chewier but there is a grilled or smoked flavor that was received very well.

When the ramen arrived, like all soups, I like to take a second or two to taste the broth by itself before loading up any condiments or additives.  I was surprised to learn that the broth was not that spicy, given the name...it was more like whispering for vengeance.  I was praying that it was a creeper and would live up to its name, but unfortunately that never happened.  Thick ramen noodles were included versus Monta and Fukumimi, which is not a bad thing for me.  If I had to choose, ranking would be Monta, Ramen Sora, then Fukumimi, when it comes to ramen noodles alone.  I am not sure if it is handmade here either.

The ramen was pretty disappointing and tasted very much like a mad scientist concoction of instant ramen packets with a heavy dose of togarashi.  My girl was not very please with her "Deluxe" as well and we decided to get it over with and get our fill before heading over to the Ice Skating Yelp event at the Cosmo, thanks Misti Y. for the free tickets...well Darlene R. thanks you, she was the Elite member to receive them.

I left the place full and can admit that the only good thing in the ramen is the red fishy chili oil sauce used to garnish the bowl of ramen, other than that, probably will have to rank  this near the bottom of the pack in terms of ramen.  Some  katsuobushi, wakame or togarashi would be nice too.  I still want to come in for the butter corn ramen since it was my initial pick.  So lesson learned, go with your instinct Yelpers.  LOL.

Oh yeah, another thing, when it comes to ramen and pho, I came to notice a lot of people are very particular to certain flavors, so much of this is to each his/her own.  I like to do research on the whole culture to know what I am searching for in good ramen or pho.  Also, forgot to mention that those that like ramen may want to try Taiwanese and Chinese noodle soup as well...Wendy's Noodle Cafe & Yi Mei Champion Taiwanese Deli.

My friends girlfriend had a get together, her Jeep truck was broken in to, we asked if they had cameras to better evidence for a police report, and they claimed that they didn't work. If anyone was to park here please ?PARK WITH CAUTION?

My disclaimer is that I'm not a huge ramen fan but my friends love the stuff. Got the miso ramen, it was better then more I've had. I'm not a huge pork eater so it kind of left me feeling meh about not having different meat options. Overall it was still good. Service was good. It was packed so that had to mean something about the food! I'd go back if it happens to land on a day they pick ramen again.

Update:  I love this place.  It's five stars all the way for me.  The corn butter miso ramen is the best.  I'm no ramen expert, but I've learned what I like and it's Ramen Sora.  The best time to come here is when they open in the morning so you don't have to wait long.  I usually have edamame first and then the big steaming bowl follows not long after.  Ramen always tastes better when it's cold outside, too.  I need to get my fix soon.  Ramen is also better with friends along, but I've also come here by myself because when you have a ramen jones, you need to feed that monster.  If you need to get your slurp on, this is the place.

The noodles are not bad broth is mediocre the egg is not running and its cold. The chasu is cold and it taste bad. The fat on the chasu taste like a pig that just got cut up after rolling in the swamp

There has been a huge ramen hype going around Colorado and there has not been a place that blew me away.  Thus, I was quite hesitant to try this place out.  However, WOW now I understand why people are so into ramen.  I have not had good ramen so this is by far the best ramen I have ever had.  My boyfriend and I were on our mini vacay when a friend of ours recommended going to this place.  Like I said, we were hesitant.  All the places we have gone to at home was quite a let down.  Nevertheless, we were pretty please with this place.  

Ramen Sora is a small restaurant with limited parking behind the restaurant.  To get seated, you have to sign yourself in on list.  This is actually very common for a lot of Asian restaurants especially in California.  I find it quite annoying because you never really get greeted.  Anyways, it wasn't long for us to get seated and for us to order.  I ordered the spicy ramen with miso broth and my boyfriend ordered the deluxe ramen with miso broth and an additional spicy meat to make it spicy.  The deluxe ramen has additional toppings, but the size was the same.  The ramen was delicious; unlike any I have had before.  However, I must say it is a bit greasy, but I much rather prefer this than all the other ramen places back home.

We got the Deluxe Sora Ramen, with shoyu base. It was pretty good for a shoyu based ramen, which I never really get. The variety of toppings was good. It was an alright ramen joint, but I probably wouldn't come back. 

I also got the gyozas, which were really good.

Wait time: it was pretty long, about 40-50 minutes on a Sunday around 12pm, about 30 minutes after they opened. It was already super packed.

Parking: kind of a small lot since it was so packed, but there's some street parking around too.
still the best ramen in vegas to me. wait time and service is slow but worth it! some say its too salty but i think it's fine the way it is

Never Had Japanese Ramen Before, & Then My Boyfriend Brought Me Here, & I Feel In Love! I've Tried 4 Other Ramen Places Here In Vegas , But Sora Has Them All Beat For sure!! we eat here every other week. Great staff and food!

One of the best places for ramen that i have tried. The portions are great, just enough to fill you up but not leave you absolutely incapacitated. The prices are average, and the service was wonderful. The food had great flavor. I got the Shoyu ramen and my husband got the Miso ramen, with gyozya and pork fried rice( which we shared). 

Cons: you have to come REALLY early or later at night because the place is small.

I am a ramen lover. I have noted that there is a great divide in the ramen world of Vegas, with many people preferring a different location and others enjoying Sora. I decided on Sora for one reason and one reason only.... they had a spicy option. I like my ramen spicy. Anyway, a friend and I came here and both got the suicide ramen (or something to that effect, it was spicy broth paired with the spicy meat). It was spicy, which I enjoyed, the noodles were not over done and the meat was tender and tasty. It was a little odd that the spicy meat was served on the side and cold, but no matter. 

My main issues with Sora are the following:
A) no tonkatsu base... I like the richness of the tonkatsu and feel that the soy base is too salty B) The giant piece of seaweed they stuck in my soup made it kinda fishy and I'm not down with that

I would like to try Monta for a proper comparison, but I have had several ramens in Phoenix that top Sora's (and Phoenix isn't exactly known for ramen so....). On the plus side, the portions were large and the prices were not so large, gotta like that!

I'm a big fan of ramen and this is my favorite ramen spot in Las Vegas. Restaurant is small, not a lot of seating but I never had to wait too long. The turnover is fast. Service is quick. I got the deluxe sora shio ramen. Portion is generous, broth was flavorful, pork was tender, and the noodles were thick and soft. Would come back here. The food is hearty and reasonably priced. Perfect meal during the Fall/Winter season

Holy Moly!  Betty had raved about this place and her enthusiasm was not misplaced.  Four of us went there for lunch... we all order (as instructed by she-who-must-be-obeyed) try the Deluxe ramen bowl with the miso broth.  This wonderfully thick broth (think broth that's like a thin gravy) has remarkable depth of flavor.  The nori sheets get crumpled in, the egg is looking at me, the noodles are things of beauty.  All this (and  we shared a pitcher of beer) left us throbulating about lunch.  

N.B.: - for an extra buck you can get a size larger.  It's a noticeable delta.  One of our bunch went for the double-wide portion (2$ extra) and it's humungous.  I'm sure I'll be back to try some of the spicier fare.
Love, love, love this place. Cannot wait to revisit Vegas so I can get my hands on some more of their ramen. Way better then what's being offered in my hometown. May have to relocate! Lol

Ahhhh Ramen Sora... An amazing bowl of legitimate ramen soup, and they don't use flavor packets!

This place is a small Restaraunt (like seats less than 20 people small) but is worth the wait! You are immediately greeted and seated with smiles, and the staff is more than happy to assist with answering questions about their specific brand of ramen.

I suggest the corn butter ramen with miso base, as this provides a pop of flavor, and the butter gives the broth a silky flavor and texture that I have yet to see matched in the ramen community. They also have options for spicy meat (or the more sinisterly named "killer spicy" meat for those who dare) if you want an extra punch of flavor. I also appreciate the firm, not soggy, noodles that are curly - not straight.

Stop in on a weekday before noon for faster seating, and faster eating!

I love spicy ramen and I have to say this place had the best, it's called "screaming for vengeance" the service was great and quick I mean the only bad part is if you have to wait outside until you are called.  

I seriously missed the broth and all its glory after every gulp, slurp and bite I had, not to mention I was left wanting more.  Screaming for Vengeance has the most extra ingredients in it so you might not have to.  If you are a big eater get the large trust me you won't regret it.  

You really can't compare the noodles or the broth to other spicy ramen and I have had my share of them.  Orochan Ramen in little Tokyo doesn't even come close to how perfectly spicy and flavorful Ramen sora made theirs, but Orochan Ramen is way spicier, now having said that I still wouldn't want Ramen Sora to change a thing.  I am really glad my friends and I tried this place out and found a gem.  It literally doesn't get better than this and I may have to attribute the balanced flavors to the noodles that were pretty eggy in flavor but hands down its probably what contributed so much to making it right, spicy and delicious.  

The restaurant is small so the capacity isn't very big it could probably fit around thirty plus people.  Come early or wait and if you do wait keep waiting because its well worth the wait.

I can't wait to come back next time I come around to vegas.

Food: Shoyu Ramen (regular) with corn added and gyoza. My bar for ramen is set high, so like others said I have yet to find my Santouka (San Jose, CA) replacement and although their soup base was less salty than Monta, the noodles were not quite al dente. Gyoza was tasty and they provided a nice dipping sauce with sesame seeds in it.

Authenticity: Japanese run (yay!)

Location: Chinatown. Small parking lot.
First time I ever finish the broth with my ramen. It's soooo good! I ordered the nori ramen with miso base broth.

Always long line.so didn't wanna wait so long for ramen.But luckily this day we didn't need to wait.

I heard a lot of too good reviews.
Yes it's okay but I don't think too good for wait so long..
Maybe expectation was so high or not my type?
  
Am I going back to here?im not sure.
If someone wanna go ,I will.if my choice is first maybe not.
I don't say that's bad.nothing complain 

Well staff was so friendly n nice.
Excellent ramen.  I got the house combo, which was good though I should have asked for less nori.   I will definately be back.

Went here because you know who had a wait out the door again so I thought I'd give this a go and I have to say that I was very surprised. I think this place beats out Monta. The ramen here as described by many others is a little heavier and has that al dente bite to it. The chashu pork is thicker and isn't a small little sliver. And I know this is super weird to say but it actually feels good in there temperature wise. I know many may think who the f- cares, but that's huge when it'll be the summertime soon and you're trying to put down a bowl of hot ramen. At Monta you're right where the kitchen is and sometimes the sun hits that window at that perfect magnifying angle where its just hot (insert hooker in church joke here) but Ramen Sora doesn't have that issue so I like that. Additionally, the service is friendly and quick.

The only thing I can say that Monta beats them out on is the broth. The broth didn't jump out at me like Montas tonkotsu-shoyu ramen. Also, theres no napkin dispenser, they just lay down one napkin. I know weird, but when you eat with a messy eater who keeps spilling soup all over himself like he's literally trying to wash his face with it, one napkin won't cut it. (Dont worry,  your sloppy table manner secrets are safe with me Steve). Outside of that though, I will definitely stop by this place first when I'm craving ramen.

This is the go to ramen place in Las Vegas for me.  The broths are incomparable and the noodles, veggies and add ons are more pleasures than one person should enjoy.  Truck stop portions in a little stand alone building w/easy access and fabulous service.

Was feeling like some warm refreshing broth and pork. Picked up my friend and drove to Ramen Sora. Wait staff was as good as can be expected from an Asian restaurant in Vegas, in other words shitty service. Now to the ramen... The fragrance was of manure and rotten eggs when I initially put my nose above the steaming bowl. The pork was funky tasting, had a strong chemical taste and the broth had no flavor, along with noodles that were overcooked and too salty.  Now, all of this I would not have noted or written a review. But, just an hour later I started experiencing digestive distress.  I thought I was just having a bad day until my friend informed me she was having the same problems.  !!!FOOD POISONING!!! Now, a full 24 hours later and I have the sweats, chills, lots of digestive issues, and can't hold any food down. My friend is experiencing much the same reaction.  
SO... Unless you want a great case of what feels like dysentery, I advise you to stay away from Ramen Sora.  Pitiful service, bad food, and a lasting memory never to be forgotten of ceramic commodes and profuse bodily explosions.

Went to LV on a business trip and ate hear 2 times after work. Everything from the broth to the chashu was amazing. If you like it spicy you have to get there spicy meat it's crazy good and the dish as a whole smacks your mouth with this umami flavor you won't soon forget. Did I mention the spicy meat I wish I knew what was in that I need to make it for myself.

Holy crap this place is cozy! I had the super spicy ramen. It was just the right amount of spicy for me. I'm Thai and Chinese, so I thought I knew all about noodles and soup. This place is special! Blew my mind!

Q: What do you call a fake noodle?  A: An impasta! 

Went on Sunday 4-17-16 at 6pm for dinner.  $17.63 got me a shio ramen, an order of pork fried rice, and a can of oolong tea.  This restaurant is located on Spring Mountain between Arville & Decatur.  

I got the shio ramen for $7.50 and added corn for $1 more.  The broth was hot and flavorful, the chasu was tender, and the noodles were perfect.  It was absolutely everything ramen should be.  I loved every hearty spoonful that slid down the back of my throat.  

The $5.85 pork fried rice was one of the best things I've ever eaten.  I shy away from bacon and pork usually but this was AMAZING.  The pork was salty and tender like pot roast and my mouth is watering right now thinking about it.  This is a must-order!!!!  

This place is every bit as delicious as Monta without having to deal with the retarded parking situation over there...I think this is my new go-to place for ramen.

I got the small version and almost busted my gut (haha) but managed to eat the whole bowl of GOODNESS.  I had the Deluxe Sora...yummmm Miso broth = thick and creamy.  The pork melts into each bite like butter.  So good and my # 2 Favorite Place after Monte.  Great also because it is larger and better chance of seating. 
Gyoza  a sure thing and the Pork fried rice..tops off the whole sha-bang.  Only problem, I ate too much!

This is by far my most favorite favvvvorite ramen place in Las Vegas! I'm definitely a noodle person and if you like your noodles with a great chewy texture, you'll love it here! The broth is the perfect amount of creamy. It's so flavorful and even if you're full, I swear you can stop! I have never everrrrr finished a bowl of ramen before. Like soup and everything! I usually order an extra egg and bamboo. I recommend the nori bowl with miso base. There is something about their miso base where it is just delicious! I took a few colleagues here and they loved it as well. The service is quick and very friendly which we really love. 

My husband got the spicy meat in his ramen. If you like the ground beef style meat, you'll enjoy it! Brings a lot of extra flavor and a mild kick to your soup. Cheers all!

Place is a decent size, not as crowded as Monta. The noodles are thicker and different from Monta's but it's a nice change.

I came with two friends and they got the miso ramen while I tried out the shio ramen for my first time. I was able to try the miso broth, and well, true to my past experiences, I've never liked miso. I preferred the shio. My bowl had a lot of oil, though. Most of it naturally from the pork or whatnot, but still, it wasn't pleasant to look at. I definitely liked the noodles. But that's mainly it. Noodles in the shio broth, that is.

Service was awesome -- our server was very friendly. They have large and XL sizes (big bowls) for those interested.

Will I be back? Yeah. Most likely to try out the other stuff.
After try monta, than compare ramen sora , they are horrible so greasy... Unless you want to be stroke, bowl of ramen is fill with fat greasy oil. Will never go back still stick with monta.

There is only one thing better than dancing naked in the rain while listening to depeche mode enjoy the silence CD; and it is having some good Ramen.

Despite the fact that my favorite miso is Monta's I cant give less than 5 stars to Sora because of its authenticity, service, portions, flavor and awesomeness. It is very hard to find something that tells you. 100% JDM , but sora does it. With its full of flavor broths ,high quality chashu , and Gyoza. this Ramen house is a must.

The place is big enough so you dont have to wait, and now that all the hipsters have tried it, there is no long wait, actually I only waited once and it was about 2 minutes.

I did their super spicy miso and it was amazing. So much flavor and an perfect punch of hotness uppercut me like Ryu or Ken on street fighter. It was simply marvelous

Best ramen in Las Vegas hands down. This place is always packed so you know it's gonna be good. I always get the spicy ramen with miso broth and it's always delicious. My husband and I probably come to Ramen Sora at least 3 times a month. Sometimes you have to wait, sometimes you don't. But let me tell you..... it's worth it! I even have taken friends from out of town here and they love it as well.

Went in just as they opened.... manager-san, can you please ask your staff to make sure that the smell of bathroom/cleanser doesn't permeate your entire shop as you open the doors? 

It was this vinegary, lemony, gross cleanser smell mixed in with sewage smell. Believe me, my kiddo noticed and his abilities rival those of Gus in "Psych". If we hadn't been part of a big group, I would have left.... 

Ramen was OK. Nothing to rival shops in LA, better than the sad ramen shops in SF, so a happy medium. Not terribly cheap, however. 

Fast service, we sat at the huge table in the centre of the shop, and it was comfy. Cheap and decent eats, but somehow I wish we had gone to Roberto's instead for lunch...

After two visits, and being a ramen freak from southerner California, here is the real deal: when I first came to Ramen Sora (and I am a gy who is planning on opening a ramen cocktail bar - aka. COCKTAIL SIDESHOW AKA. VALHALLA RAMEN) ...' I loved it anf swore it as the best ramen ever. Now, after a second visit, I know why: it is basically the second best ramen broth ever. The second best chashu pork ive ever had. The second best noodles.... it is a close second in every category.... what that means? It meana that in any two - or more categories - of ramen, itis in the top two. Meaning its the best overall of any ramen. Other shit has great broth, great pork, great noodles, great atmosphere..... but thats it. This place has almost great EVERYTHING

*Thumbs up*
If there's a long frickin' wait for Monta a few blocks down and you are literally dying of ramen starvation, then Ramen Sorta will suit you just fine without the long wait. I tried the shoyu and spicy miso ramen and it was fine. Ample seating, good spacious, and a friendly staff. 

*Thumbs down*
The ramen does it's job to satisfy your ramen cravings, but it doesn't compare to Monta. Sure, you can get down to the nitty gritty and say you can't compare the two because of different ramen styles, but I ain't going that deep.

I never turn down a good hot bowl of ramen!  I had the Deluxe and it was one of the best I've ever had.  The broth was spot on, the noodles cooked al dente, the charsiu so soft and buttery, the tamago and the garnish of seaweed, spring onions & garlic made the whole dish.  The gyoza was ok.  Service was attentive.  Parking lot is a little small.  I like their motto "No ramen no life".  How true!
The miso ramen is amazing!!! Hubby got the spicy miso ramen and he said is was really good...he still added siracha to it because he likes it really spicy!!! I definitely recommend going here!

Small restaurant but delicious. The spicy ramen is the best I've had and their curry dish is amazing. I can split a large ramen and small curry and be totally satisfied. Pricing is good too. Love eating here.

(4.5 STAR) Favorite Japanese ramen place in Vegas! Although the wait can be long, it's worth the wait. I'm giving a 4.5 because the servers can be rude sometimes.. I mean most of the time. This one time, one of the servers was being very rude about splitting checks. Everything else was good. I go there for the food, I don't expect much from their customer service.

Originally my friend wanted to go to Manta but as we arrived at around 10pm it was packed so using the knowledge of Yelp, we went down the street to Ramen Sora which was strangely not very crowded. As we ate, more people rolled in so that was a good sign.

Our waitress was very nice, and helped explain the menu to my friend, who really needs to see a photo to understand what she is ordering hahaha. I chose the Miso based ramen and she choose the salt based one. Delivered quickly and very hot, I thought both were pretty tasty. My friend thought mine was much better and wanted to trade, but I laughed and said "not a chance". 

Prices were cheaper than Manta, and it was pretty good, although not something I'd order on a hot summer night. I need to get my friend to try things like salads.

Overall, I'd go back.

Insanely busy and magically delicious. 

I kind of wish I could just leave my review there, but maybe I can ramble on a little. 

Always a wait, so don't come starving. Just come medium-hangry and by the time you sit, you'll feel good.

Delicious ramen - I've tried a few different kinds and there hasn't been one I didn't enjoy. Just come, wait a while, and enjoy. It's loud inside, because it's a tiny place with limited seating and people slurping their soup, but it's worth it.

Favorite ramen spot. I've been to a few Ramen spots in Vegas and this one takes the cake. The food taste great and the servers are friendly. Only thing I hate about this place is the wait especially lunch time.

been here numerous times, but finally took the time to write a review.  
funny story, ive been here so many times during my earlier years i got sick of it.  i recently returned and found it enjoyable.  it would taste a lot better during the winter, but still soothes the soul during the summer heat.

you have the option of getting 1 of 3 bases.  miso, shoyu, or shio.  I typically go with miso since i feel like it'll have the most flavor.  i was able to sample the button corn ramen and the deluxe sora ramen. both are good, and are distinct.  they also don't skimp out on the meats... which i find really surprising.  
they also have small rice plates if you're a fatass like myself.  

lines can be a little long during lunch as some people prefer to eat/drink ramen after a night of drinking to cure their hangovers.  

one of my friends told me this...when you get older, you go to vegas to grub and not to club.  lol, so true.
The food will be delicious but if you don't like pork don't come!! Everything is made with pork broth..

I was excited to read there's Sapporo style ramen noodles in Vegas so I made it a goal to try Ramen Sora. Sadly this place did not deliver. The broth lacks flavor and is overall bland. I relocated to Vegas from SF where we are truly spoiled with numerous ramen joints. I've also had ramen in LA and this place falls at the bottom of all the ramen places I have been to. 

My husband and I came in at lunch on a Saturday. Upon entering the establishment we noticed they only really have ten small tables and the place was pretty empty for lunch on a sat
Never ate ramen before but I would eat here again. The buttered corn was awesome.

My boyfriend and I love ramen. We went to ramen sora because his cousin told us it's the best ramen in Las Vegas and I think I have to agree. 

The only downside is that there's no tonkotsu, which is my boyfriends fav. He got the shoyu tho and said it was really good which is saying a lot for someone who orders exclusively tonkotsu. He said the chashu was one of the best he has had. 

I got the spicy miso and it was the perfect amount of spicy! Everything was so delicious! The slice of pork I got was way too salty tho, and that was my only negative. 

Beware: this place is pretty small so not ideal for big parties! A party of 8-10 people came shortly after I did, and they had to wait a while only to end up being split up.

I wake up and roll over and think to myself what is my tummy craving? Wait, what is that you say? Rammmmmen.... But not just the packaged dried crap you get at the discount aisle. It's calling for that savory umami brothy goodness that is cooked for days on end that with one taste brings you to an eye rolling ecstasy.What is the only place that comes to mind when I think about this? Ramen Sora. Hands down the best ramen I have ever had. 

It starts when you first enter the door. You get greeted with a loud and warm "Irasshaimase!" and for that split second you get sucked into a vortex and transported into Japan. 

The ramen? Killer. The broth? Exceptional. The chasu pork? Tender and flavorful. Mix them all together into one bowl? A flavor combination that will have your head spin. Get the miso ramen and the umami level goes up to 11. It's a pure delight to have one of these savory and rich ramen dishes all at a small price of  $10. 

With the cold weather upon us, this will be on my return often list. I can't get enough of them. They win. Take my money!

Get out of the way Monta there is a new king in town and it's called Ramen Sora.

They lie about there closing time walked in at 10:32 and they said they closed. Their closing time says on the door says 11pm and on this site it says 11pm. Two mins pass what they say is last seating and they not willing to seat us. Plus they not even busy and they have open seats. Horrible customer service. One of the workers also came outside and gave me attitude for writing a review. She said what you can't see it's posted on the sign last call 10:30.

Three of us decided to drive across time and try out this highly rated ramen spot. There is not a lot of seating, but it was only an eighteen-minute wait on a Saturday evening. The A/C was not working well, and they had a portable unit inside, though it could not keep up with the heat. Service was very quick. We started with pot stickers, which were fine, but nothing special. (Same with the Mini-Chashu bowl) As for the ramen, I had the Shoyu, and my wife had the Miso, and both were tasty. In the end, it was good, though not our favorite in town.

Still the best miso ramen in Vegas, and even compared to some places in Japan. 
I went for the regular spicy miso instead of the vengeance, since I don't want to have to buy Tucks tomorrow. 

Spicy fried rice wasn't spicy at all, and was a bit bland in my opinion. 

I haven't been here in 1.5 years, so I'm glad they are keeping in real. 

I absolutely love their chashu here...fatty, tender piece of pork.

Terrible service. I was hoping the food would be good, but no. The curry is too salty and the ramen tastes cheap. You can find better priced food that tastes much better at other places. Also if you call ahead make sure they get your order perfect if not you'll end up wasting time waiting for your order you made correctly the first time.

Admittedly I was quite hungry and with numerous visits to Monta, a favorite when I visit Vegas, the crew decided to try something new based on another friend's recommendation.

Correct there is no tonkotsu style choices here, but I tried the Deluxe Sora in Shoyu flavor. In short great al dente noodles, nice egg but the highlight was the char shiu. Some places cut razor thin slices, some places give you chunks, darn it I like chunky slices and wow wow wow did they exceed my expectations on that. A mere $2.50 for another generous three slices? I'm in! I admit it was gluttonous but oh so worth it. Flavorful broth, very good portions and the char shiu upgrade to me is so worth it.

Yes our friend said this place is just as popular as other highly reviewed ramen joints in LV, so avoid peak hours or you may have to stand in the hot sun.

Another 5 star experience as always. Mmmmm I love the Chashu ramen with miso broth. Of course we ordered a pitcher of Kirin Japanese beer. The service is great as well, the staff knows how to please. This is my favorite ramen joint, the flavor is always consistent.
Place can get busy at times but if you want spicy ramen this is really the only place in town that has one truly spicy!

So this past week I've been having a crave for some ramen. Went to Monta Ramen in Henderson and order some up. I like my ramen with some spice, so I noticed that they started to offer a spicy sauce upon request. So spicy ramen with chachu it was. It was good but in the end some thing was a bit lacking. The broth had flavor but not a rich taste and the spicy sauce was ok a bit weak in my opinion. Couple of days later, next stop Sora Ramen. Ordered the same, the difference is  noticeable the broth here has a deep rich pork flavor wether it is miso, shoyu or shiso. Even the flavor and look of the chachu has is better here. As for the spiciness? You can ask for a scoop of "Killer Meat", which is ground meat cooked in, from what I'm told, 15 different types chili for a long time.  This gives it a nice deep spicy flavor that gives a bold flavor but won't leave you crying . In my opinion Sora tops in all categories from basic to spicy. They offer a variety of add-ins such as corn, butter and extra meat. If you go, get there early as this place gets packed. Highly recommend.

The original place we wanted to go to was closed due to an emergency so we ended up trying this place. It was ok, you have to sign in and wait because the location is small. The service was alright. Not much to really choose from like the other place we had in mind but we still enjoyed ourselves.

I'm so happy about the ramen scene in LV.  Back in KS, Neoguri is my best option.  

So the other day I went to Monta.  It's hard to compare the two b/c we did tonkatsu there and that option isnt avail here.  Instead we asked for their most popular options, which were the house and the spicy, so we opted for the latter and chose a miso broth (shio and shoyu were the other options).  For on $1, we upgraded to the large, which is like kaedama.  We only ordered one bowl to share bc our past few days of gluttony is catching up to us!

So I like the noodle here a lot more.  It's thicker and not over-cooked.  And even though I always prefer tonkotsu, this broth was delish!  And the spicy is not wimpy at all.  As for the fixings, there was a good amount of it, and the chashu was even tastier than Monta's.  The soft boiled egg was a bit overdone, but still good.

I was surprised how quickly the restaurant fills up. We got there at opening, and a line quickly formed.  

I enjoyed my experience at Sora.  Def better than a lot of places I've tried on the East Coast.

This place is well loved and you can tell when you walk up because there is a line at the door before they open.

Things to love.

+The ramen is so good. I ordered the corn ramen and it was perfection. I loved the broth and the noodles and it was amazing. I wish I could add more about the depth of flavors but I'm a noodle newbie.

+The decor. It's small and efficient and straightforward. 

What left me wanting more.

+The service. The water I was served was half-full and the ordering process was rushed. A little patience and kindness goes a long way and I'm new to the ramen world. I fully admit that I need a little hand holding when it comes to ramen and noodles in general. 

This isn't a place where I felt like I could take the server's time by asking questions but that doesn't mean the food it's delicious AF. Now I know that I need to dine here with an experienced ramen connoisseur. 

Yum yum.

Best ramen I've ever had! The deluxe number 1 is amazing.  I could eat this everyday. I've been to a lot of other ramen joints in vegas like Tatsu,  Monta,  Omoide, fukumimi, jinya, and Moko but this place is the best.

Got the Spicy Shoyu Ramen which had robust flavor and perfectly hit the spot. 

I have to say in a comparison, Ramen Sora is probably #1 on my list of Japanese noodle houses right now. 

Will definitely be back!

We found this little ramen joint when we first moved to Vegas in August 2014. Three years later, it's still our favorite place to go.

The ramen is delicious - my usual is spicy miso ramen with extra bamboo (menma). Gyoza is always perfectly cooked. Fried rice is well seasoned. 

The staff is amazing. Always a smile on their face and are very quick - even during the mealtime rush hours. 

I always recommend this place to my friends and family!

Drove all the way from the east side because of the reviews, 25 min drive FYI. I call at 10:43 to place an order for pick up. Keep in mind I was already parked in the back of your restaurant. I wanted 5 ramen soups and 2 appetizers but the man that answered the phone told me they were already closed. That the kitchen closes at 10:30. I even told him I was already outside and he said sorry we are closed. I guess your hours of business should say 10:30pm instead 11pm. Guess I will have to go to Pho Kim long :( no ramen for me

yummy ramen. small restaurant outside of the vegas strip with a casual atmosphere. really good fried rice too, I liked almost as much as my ramen. wasn't crazy about the fragrant bamboo shoots in the ramen. broth was super soothing, quick service :)
Best ramen around! Always super fast service and the ramen is incredible. Get the miso chashu corn butter!
A bowl of thick, fatty heaven. This is the best ramen I've had outside of Japan.

This place just always gives me comfort. It's only been a few times that I've been here, but every time I'm here (which is usually me after work all exhausted and cranky still in my work uniform), Mo always helps me out with what I want and not to mention so friendly and quick at her service! I always order atleast 2 large sakes, she's just awesome. 
This time, it was an 9 hour shift for me so I just came in for gyoza (I know they're frozen, but growing up in okinawa, I still think they're delicious) and rice and almost 3 large sakes.  
Thank you Mo for always making my experience great! I'll be back after works as long as it's open!

A must go-to place! This is one of my favorite places to get some good ramen. Monta is a good place too which is also close by but the portion sizes here are better in my opinion. Friendly staff and a popular place. I always go here with my friends. I recommend the Chashu Ramen and Spicy Ramen. My two favs. Other than that, the waiting list is kinda long but it's understandable.

I wanted to love you Ramen Sora. But in the end, I am not sure I feel about you.

You walk in and get this amazing welcome. 
The place was definately smaller than I thought. I mean I know it's a small building, I just thought they would have had more chairs and tables inside.

I have been wanting to try this place since it first opened and I finally did one day during my lunch break. I arrived shortly after opening time and it was quiet but boy oh boy did that place fill up very quickly.

I ordered the spicy hot soup (can't remember the name)  with shoyu broth but very similar to the deluxe. I added bean sprouts to my soup and also ordered the gyoza.

My Ramen was just okay. I don't know if it was the reviews that I read that let me down or if I am a Ramen snob. Either way, it was just okay. The broth was good, flavorful, the noodles were neither here nor there for me. The noodles I was not a fan of. I love a good chew to my noodle but these just didn't work for me.
